loans.name: Munhbayar

texts.en:
Munhbayar is a 23-year-old man who lives with his wife and two daughters in Chingeltei district, Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a "ger", a Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent, in his parents' backyard. His two daughters haven’t reached school age, so they stay home with their nanny. 

Munhbayar manages a grocery trading business with the help of his wife. He started his business in 2006 in a rented stall at Bumbugur trading center, one of the busiest markets in Ulaanbaatar city. His monthly rent is 140,000 MNT. Since last year his wife began to conduct their business independently and Munhbayar started working as a designer at a private company. He is a polite man who says, "My wife and I are doing our best to provide better living conditions for our children." He is requesting a 2,300,000 MNT loan to purchase more grocery products to increase his sales.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products.

loans.name: Geronica

texts.en:
Geronica is from the village of Palilan, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 31 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Geronica runs a business venture in the food sector selling fish. Her main source of income comes from selling fish in the local community.

Geronica has been engaged in her business for 10 years and earns approximately 2900 PHP a month for these activities. Geronica joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase more fish to sell.

Geronica is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP with which will serve as financing in repairing her fishing boat for her fishing activity. This will be the 12th loan taken out by her from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair her fishing boat for fishing activity

loans.name: Rozbek

texts.en:
Rozbek is 37 years old and lives with his wife and three children in their own house in Hovd province, Mongolia. His three children all attend local secondary school. His wife is a cook who manages a cafe in their town. Rozbek is a driver and operates a transportation service in his town. 

Rozbek worked as a driver at a private company for 6 years and started his business in 2004 with his own truck. Besides his transportation service he conducts a vegetable planting and selling business in order to contribute to his family earnings. He is an open-minded and diligent man who says, "I am planning to plant more vegetables this year." He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase some auto parts for his truck and some seeds for his vegetable planting business.

loans.use: To purchase some auto parts.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon M. is from the village of Tagdo, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 37 years old. Corazon is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Corazon owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling coconuts & bananas in the local community. Corazon has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Corazon joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Corazon is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional coconuts & bananas. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Corazon from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional coconuts & bananas.

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
This is Adelaida G., 50, a resident of Victoria Reyes, Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Jenard G., a government employee, and is the mother of three children. Two of them are still studying in high school while the other one is already married.  At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Adelaida, as she herself is an elementary graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Adelaida operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP’s-worth of cooking oil or an egg. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at retail piece rates. She earns a minimum of 300 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her variety store, she is requesting a 36,000 PHP loan.  She plans to use this loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages so as to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Adelaida dreams of being able to give all of her children a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work in her business. She also plans on having her own rice retailing outlet and being an even more successful businesswoman someday. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group’s weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives. 

*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional grocery items for her store.

loans.name: Zereg

texts.en:
Zereg is 23 years old and lives with his wife and two children in their own house in Hovd province, Mongolia. His wife is unemployed an takes care of their children. He manages a public transportation service business between two provinces. He started his business in 2008 with the help of his older brother. Since then his business has been quite successful and allowed him to conduct his business independently. 

Besides his transportation business he manages a vegetable planting business in order to contribute to his family earnings. He is planning to buy a car for his wife which can be used in a taxi service business. He is a polite man who attributes his business success to his good accounting skills. He says, "I want to have an apartment in the future." He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT of loan to purchase a car.

loans.use: To purchase a car which can be used as a taxi.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is 47 years old and has two children. The oldest child is 23 years old.

Judith is a farmer working in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She has been growing rice for 30 years. She sells her harvest at the market. Judith also manages a small eatery and videoke shop. Judith works hard to improve her businesses and to be able to sustain her family.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizer and seeds.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
Rachel L. is from the village of Bug-ong, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 28 years old. Rachel is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Rachel owns & operates recycling services. The main source of income for the business comes from buying  plastics, bottles, steel bars & other recyclables from local businesses and community members and reselling them. Rachel has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Rachel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rachel is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional plastics & other recyclables to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Rachel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional plastics & other recyclables to sell

loans.name: Enhtuvshin

texts.en:
Enhtuvshin is 46 years old and lives with his wife and two children in their own house in Dornod province, Mongolia. His older daughter is a student while his younger one helps with the family business. He manages a good trading business at a border city of Mongolia. Before his business operation he used to work as a driver in his younger brother's company for 10 years. He started a motorcycle trading business three years ago and gained much experience. Also, he sells grocery products such is a rice, flour, etc. 

Even within this short period of time, he has managed to build a strong customer base and a good relationship with his suppliers. He is planning to expand his business in the future. He is a serious man who attributes his business success to his good accounting skills. He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT of loan to purchase more products and to increase his business sales.

loans.use: To purchase more products for resale.

loans.name: Narantsetseg

texts.en:
Narantsetseg is 39 years old and lives with her husband and three children in a house in Dornod province of Mongolia. Her older daughter is a student and the younger two are pupils. Her husband is a sculptor who is planning to start his own business in the near future.

 Narantsetseg manages a grocery trading business in her town. She started her business in 2009 in a rented stall at a grocery trading center. Within three years of business operation, she managed to expand and stabilize her business and opened her own grocery store. She is planning to deposit her business earnings in savings to buy a car in the future. 

 Narantsetseg is a diligent woman who attributes her business success to her good communication skills. She says, "I would like my children to be educated and have a nice life." She is requesting an 800,000 MNT of loan to purchase more grocery goods.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery goods.

loans.name: Naida

texts.en:
Naida is from the village of Adorable, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 58 years old, married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Naida buys and sells coconuts in the local community. 

Naida has been engaged in her business for 5 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities. Naida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase coconuts to sell.

Naida is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP with which she will purchase additional coconuts to sell. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Naida from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy more coconuts to sell.

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
This is Rowena B., 41, a resident of Brgy. Bautista, Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Wilson B., a landscaping artist, and is the mother of six children. Three of them are studying at high school, two are in elementary grades and the other one is in college.  

At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Rowena, as she herself was an elementary graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Rowena has been managing her own landscaping business for quite some time now. She is partnering with her husband in operating this business. Rowena offers landscaping services to individuals who desire to beautify their home gardens. She also sells ornamental plants and other landscaping materials for hobbyists and even schools in her local community. Rowena earns an estimated net income of 12,000 PHP a month. 

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 50,000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business to buy supplies and other materials for their landscaping needs.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for supplies and other materials for landscaping needs.

loans.name: Meldirose

texts.en:
Meldirose S. is from the village of Balila, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 35 years old. Meldirose is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Meldirose owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, breads, biscuits, shampoo, soap and beverages in the local community. Meldirose has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Meldirose joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Meldirose has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Meldirose is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, beverages and snack foods. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Meldirose from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, beverages and snack foods

loans.name: Dolgor

texts.en:
Dolgor T. is 45 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in their own house in the Hovd province of Mongolia. Her older son is unemployed while the younger one attends college. Her husband is a driver who conducts a taxi service business. 

She manages a timber trading business in her town. She started her business last year. She is planning to continue her business in the future. She is a polite woman who says, "I am trying hard to feed my family." 

She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT of loan to purchase more wood for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more wood.

loans.name: Ma. Bella

texts.en:
Ma. Bella is 40 years old and is a married woman with five children. Her oldest child is 20 years old and the youngest is only seven.

Ma. Bella is a farmer working in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She grows rice and then sells her harvest to the market. Aside from farming, Ma. Bella also buys and resells chicken eggs.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizer and buy more eggs to resell. In the future, Ma. Bella hopes to have a stable business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and buy more eggs to sell

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie P. is from the village of Balila, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 29 years old. Melanie is married and has two infants. To make a living, Melanie owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling canned goods, powdered juice, junk foods, beverages, shampoo, soap & biscuits in the local community. Melanie's husband is providing motorela or habal-habal services (motorcycles that can handle multiple passengers). Melanie has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Melanie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melanie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Melanie is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods & beverages. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Melanie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods & beverages

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora B. is from the village of Kulasihan, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 39 years old. Dora is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Dora owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling canned goods, instant noodles, detergents, shampoo, soap & ready-to-wear clothing in the local community. Dora has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 14,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Dora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Dora is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products, such as canned goods and junk foods. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Dora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional products, such as canned goods & junk foods

loans.name: Cerelina

texts.en:
Cerelina G. is from the village of Poblacion, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 47 years old. Cerelina is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Cerelina owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling canned goods, junk foods, detergents, shampoo, soap & beverages in the local community. Cerelina has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Cerelina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cerelina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Cerelina is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods and junk foods. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Cerelina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods & junk foods

loans.name: Adelina

texts.en:
This is Adelina E., 49, a resident of Victoria Reyes, Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Vicente E., a seafarer. She finished high school and decided to run a rice retailing outlet as a source of income for her family. 

Adelina has been operating a rice retailing business for quite some time now. She buys sacks of rice at a wholesale price and retails the same per kilo with minimum mark up. In the Philippines, almost all Filipinos are rice consumers since rice has always been a part of their daily meals. Serving her local community, Adelina earns an estimated net income of around 12,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) a month. 

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 25,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this loan to buy more sacks of rice for retailing. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Adelina always desires a happy and abundant life. She prays that her business will continue to grow and be of help not only to her family but also to her relatives and neighbors. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship meeting* where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studied. 

*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for sacks of rice for retailing

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
48-year-old Merlinda is a farmer living in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She is married and has eight children. Her oldest child is already 31 years old and the youngest is only five.

Merlinda grows rice on their farm. Her husband, who is also a farmer, mainly manages their rice farm. Merlinda also raises pigs in her backyard. She fattens the pigs and sells them to the market.

Merlinda's loan will be used to purchase rice seed, fertilizer and piglets.

loans.use: to purchase rice seed, fertilizer and piglets

loans.name: Jeanita

texts.en:
Jeanita is from the village of Tubod, Aloran, Misamis, Occidental. She is 46 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Jeanita sells rice in her community. 

Jeanita has been engaged in her business for two years and earns approximately 3000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) a month from it. Jeanita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase sacks of rice to sell. 

Jeanita is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP with which she will purchase additional inventory and use for working capital. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Jeanita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About PMPC 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of rice for her rice store

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married and has grown children. She is a small market entrepreneur from Novaya Kahovka. Irina sells sport shoes and sport clothing in one of the local markets. Irina rents a small facility that serves as a vending outlet. 

She says that she started this business because it was the only way to survive when her family was going through some challenging financial times. Irina has been in this business for 9 years. Irina enjoys her business, has a long-term view of her venture development and is disciplined with all her business plans. 

Irina has used micro-loans in the past and found them very helpful for her business. This time Irina is requesting a 20,000 Grivnyas loan to purchase 200 pairs of sport shoes and 50 items of various sport clothing.

loans.use: to purchase 200 pairs of sport shoes and 50 items of various sport clothing

loans.name: Anabel

texts.en:
Anabel P. is from the village of Poblacion, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 38 years old. Anabel is married and has five school-aged children. Anabel owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling canned goods, junk food, breads, shampoo, soap, & biscuits in the local community. Anabel has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 6000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2010, Anabel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 5000 PHP and was used to purchase additional inventory & for working capital. 

This loan will be her second from HSPFI. Anabel is requesting 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, breads, & beverages. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI: 

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, breads, & beverages

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
This is Teresita S., 49, a resident of San Andres 2, Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Rolando S., an employee of a private firm, and is the mother of three children. One of their children is in high school, while the other two not yet of school age. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Teresita, as she herself has been a high school graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children. 

Teresita has been in the direct sales business for almost three years now. She sells branded cosmetics, apparel, footwear, household detergents, and other personal products. She allows her customers to order from her based on a product catalog, then orders these items from the company office at a discounted price. Monthly, Teresita earns an estimated net income of around 11,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). 

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting an 18,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this loan to buy items ordered in advance by her customers like cosmetics and apparels. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Teresita dreams of being able to give all of her children a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work in her business. She prays that her business will become successful and aims for financial stability someday. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship meeting* where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for cosmetics and other personal products ordered in advance by her customers

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes is from the village of Poblacion II, Oroquieta City. She is 45 years old, married and has four adult children. To make a living, Lourdes raises pigs. 

Lourdes has been engaged in her business for 10 years and earns approximately 6000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Lourdes joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase pigs to sell. 

Lourdes is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP with which she will purchase pigs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About PMPC 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase pigs

loans.name: Evans

texts.en:
Evans is a married man with one child who attends school. His wife is a businesswoman and she supports the family with the earnings from her business. They live at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expense is school fees for his child. 

For the past two years, he has operated a spare parts business, selling oil, tubes and tires at the market to his neighbours and motorcycles operators. Evans not only depends on his spare parts shop but he also operates a butcher shop. He faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. 

With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) loan he is requesting he wants to purchase oil, tubes and tires for sale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase oil, tubes, and tires for sale

loans.name: Cherryl

texts.en:
This is Cherryl Sta. A., 29, a resident of San Nicolas III, Bacoor, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Sanly Sta. A., a waiter, and is the mother of three children. Two of her children are in elementary school, while the other one is not yet of school age. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Cherryl, as she herself has been a high school graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children. 

Cherryl operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that sells groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five pesos 'worth of cooking oil or an egg. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at retail piece rates. She earns a minimum of 200 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day. 

To help her continue operation of her variety store, she is requesting a 16,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries, and beverages so as to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Cherryl dreams of being able to give all of her children a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work in her business. She also prays that her business will become bigger and that she eventually will own a convenience store. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship meeting* where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional grocery items for her variety store

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
This is Cristina C., 31, a resident of San Nicolas III, Bacoor, Cavite City, Philippines. She is a high school graduate and married to Rolly C., a mason. They are praying that God will bless them with children to complete the family. 

Cristina operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five pesos'-worth of cooking oil or an egg. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at retail piece rates. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day. 

To help her continue operating her variety store, she is requesting a 16,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries, and beverages so as to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Cristina hopes that her business will become bigger, allowing her to enjoy life with simplicity, peace, and good health. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship meeting* where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional grocery items for her variety store

loans.name: Gulnara's Group

texts.en:
Gulnara K., 48, is the leader of this group. She lives in the town of Kochkorka with her husband and their nine-year-old son, their only financial dependent. In 1994 Gulnara received a piece of land after the collapse of Soviet Union and the Act of Privatization. Having been a farmer for her entire lifetime, Gulnara  decided without any hesitation to continue farming after the country gained independence. She stayed faithful to cultivating the land and cattle breeding. 

Fall is the noblest season for a farmer. In one such fall, she organized a wedding ceremony for their oldest son. In future she hopes to continue improving the state of her business and hopes the loan from Kiva lenders will help her to meet the family needs. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to meet family needs.

loans.name: Gulmira's Group

texts.en:
Gulmira I., 48, is the leader of this group. She resides in Tyup, is married to technician, and has four children, the youngest of whom is sixteen. Her husband takes care of the field work when he’s free, while Gulmira  has been running a dairy business for thirteen years now, yielding 5-6 liters of milk, which is sold for 11 soms per liter. 

The family is busy with field work with the start of spring. They used to rent out their land, but this year Gulmira decided to start using the land herself. She plans to sow wheat and gain a rich harvest in fall. The purpose of the loan is a purchase of 200 kg of wheat seeds and 200 liters of fuel for equipment. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.
 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase 200 kg of wheat seeds and 200 liters of fuel.

loans.name: Santo

texts.en: Santo is currently in business selling alcohol. She is 48 years old, married, with six children and three of them go to school. Santo borrowed a loan to stock more alcohol to sell. She hopes to pay for her children in school in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: to stock more alcohol to sell.

loans.name: Agulu

texts.en: L. is currently in business selling soft drinks. She is 38 years old, married, with four children and two of them go to school. L. borrowed a loan to stock more soft drinks to sell. She hopes to build a house for rent in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: to stock more soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Rawda

texts.en:
Rawda is a 47-year-old ambitious lady. She felt the need to do something in her life that could bring her some income, so she started selling accessories from her house four years ago.

Through these four years, her business was so successful that she was able to open a small shop of her own to sell all kinds of accessories and she started also to sell perfumes at the shop.

Now Rawda wants to extend her shop and turn in into a gift shop to include all kind of gifts beside the accessories and perfumes. That’s why she applied for this loan.

loans.use: To extend her shop and turn it into a gift shop.

loans.name: Stepen

texts.en: V. is currently in business selling alcohol. She is 38 years old, married, with six children and all of them go to school. V. borrowed a loan to stock more alcohol to sell. She hopes to  pay for her children in school with extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: to stock more alcohol to sell.

loans.name: Gulbiyo

texts.ru: Суфиева Гулбиё проживает в районе Дангара. Ей 38 лет. Она вдова, имеет троих детей. У нее средне - специальное образование, товаровед. Она в основном занимается торговлей на рынке. Имеет магазин, где продает продукты питания. В этой области уже 10 лет. Ее дети учатся, а старший сын помогает ей в её деятельности. Она просит кредит для покупки масла, муки и конфет. То есть для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en: Gulbiyo S. lives in Dangara. She is 38 years old, a widow, and has three children. She has a vocational education as a sales manager. She trades in the market. She has a shop where she sells foodstuffs. She has been doing this work for ten years.  Her children go to school, and the eldest son helps her at work.  She is asking for a loan to buy oil, flour and candy. This will increase the variety of goods she is able to sell.

loans.use: to buy oil, flour and candy

loans.name: Ismael

texts.en:
Ismael is a 46-year-old married man, who has experience in making perfumes.

To be able to support his family he decided to use his experience in making perfumes three years ago and open a specialty store to make and sell perfumes. During these years he gained a lot of customers and forged a good reputation.

Ismael is now applying for a loan in order to expand his shop since he wants to include selling cosmetics, too.

loans.use: To expand his shop and include selling cosmetics.

loans.name: Abalo

texts.en: M. is currently in business selling beans and maize flour. She is 28 years old, with five children and four of them go to school. M. borrowed a loan to stock more beans and maize flour to sell. She hopes to pay for her children in school with extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: to stock more beans and maize flour to sell.

loans.name: Ramon

texts.en:
Ramon lives in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato with his family. He is engaged in hog-raising and farming businesses. Ramon has a backyard piggery where he fattens the pigs and sells them to the market. He also grows rice crops on his farm. Ramon also sells his rice to the market.

Ramon's loan will be used to purchase feed, piglets and fertilizer. He hopes for his businesses to help improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase feed, piglets and fertilizer

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine M. is married and mother of two children. Her husband is employed and offers support in the family’s upkeep. Josephine runs a bread depot in Mariakani and she has been in this business for 11 years. The business is a success.

This is Josephine’s second time borrowing from KADET and she plans to purchase thirty crates of bread for her shop for re-selling. The income and profits she hopes to make will be directed into servicing the loan and to purchasing more stock of bread. 

Josephine hopes to become a very successful businesslady in Mariakani

loans.use: purchase thirty crates of bread.

loans.name: Basiliza

texts.en:
Basiliza C. is a lady of forty-six, married and a mother of four children. They live in Cheplaskei on the outskirts of Eldoret, and she has done maize farming in the same area for the last seven years. She gets a monthly income of seven thousand shillings.


Basiliza plans to use the loan to buy maize seed and, fertilizer and use part of the money for weeding. She will use the additional income that she will get to pay back the loan and to expand her agricultural business. 



In future she wants to improve her family's living standards.

loans.use: To buy maize seeds and  fertilizer.

loans.name: Violah

texts.en:
Violah J. R. is a single lady of twenty-nine who lives in Cheplasgei on the outskirts of Eldoret. She keeps poultry for sale in the same area and has been in this business for six years now. She gets a monthly income of KES.7,000.


This will be Violah's fourth loan from KADET LTD. She plans to use the entire loan to buy poultry feed and add more chicks to raise.

With the additional income that she will get she wants to buy more poultry so that she can expand her business. In future she wants to build rental houses so that she can add to her income.

loans.use: To buy poultry feed and more chicks to rear.

loans.name: Mahmadmurod

texts.ru: Содиков Махмадмурод проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 32 года. Женат. Имеет 4 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Махмадмурод занимается растениеводством. Он в основном арендует земельный участок, где сеет пшеницу и сажает фруктовые деревья. Этим видом деятельности занимается 10 лет. Кредит берет для закупа семян.
texts.en: Mahmadmurod S. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. He is 32 years old, married, and has four children. His wife is a housewife. Mahmadmurod works in agriculture.  He basically rents a plot of land where he sows wheat and plants fruit trees. He has been doing this work for ten years.  He is taking out a loan to buy seeds.

loans.use: to buy seeds

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Anna R., 30 years old, is currently in business selling fish. She is married to a teacher and they have four children going to school. Her future goal is to buy more goods from her business profit.

loans.use: to stock more fish.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice C. S. is a married woman of twenty-eight and a mother of two school-going children. They live in Cheplaskei on the outskirts of Eldoret. She sells new handbags and has been doing so for four years now. She gets a monthly income of seven thousand shillings.


This will be Beatrice's third loan from KADET LTD. With this loan she plans to buy more handbags for sale. The income generated  will be ploughed back into her business by buying more handbags for sale. 



In future she would like to educate her children to the highest level.

loans.use: To buy new handbags for sale.

loans.name: Mohssen

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 57 years old, married and has three children who all work.

In 1979, Mohssen inherited a farm with calves from his family. He sells all kinds of dairy products. He gained experience with time. He has a good reputation and he is well known in his area.

He is requesting a $2,400 loan to buy a Friesian (dairy) cow and to build a roof for the farm. He aspires to buy more cows to increase milk production so he will be able to improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a Friesian cow and to build a roof for the farm.

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida is from the village of Conat, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old, married and has four adult children. To make a living, Leonida runs a business venture in the food sector selling fish. Her main source of income comes from selling fish in the local community.

Leonida has been engaged in her business for 12 years and earns approximately 8500 PHP a month for these activities. Leonida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fish to sell.

Leonida is requesting a new loan of 50000 PHP with which she will purchase additional inventory. This will be the second loan taken out by Leonida from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma S. is from the village of Mambuaya, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 47 years old. Emma is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Emma owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, shampoo, soap, biscuits & coconuts in the local community. Emma has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Emma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Emma is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & coconuts. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Emma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & coconuts.

location.town: Mambuaya, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Lilias

texts.en: Lilias I., 32 years old, is currently in business selling fruit and vegetables. She is married to a farmer and they have three children; all of them are going to school. Her future goal is to build a big house.

loans.use: to stock more fruit and vegetables.

loans.name: Malish

texts.en: R. is currently in business doing photocopying, printing and scanning. She is 35 years old, divorced, with two children and both of them go to school. R. borrowed a loan to stock more machines for photocopying, printing and scanning. She hopes to expand and pay for her children in school in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: to stock more machines for photocopying, printing and scanning.

loans.name: Areej

texts.en:
Areej is a 22-year-old lady who lives in a rented house. At first she was trying to think of a way to help in paying the rent so, a year ago, she started a small home business using her artistic skills and creative ideas.

Areej was known for her skill at working with straw, so she started making straw baskets and beautiful frames and selling them. She also does flower organizing for speciA. occasions.

Doing that for a year made her want more success, so now she is applying for a loan to help her expand her business and have her own shop in the future.

loans.use: To help her expand her business and have her own shop in the future.

loans.name: Dushekan's Group

texts.en:
Dushekan K., 55, is the leader of this group. She is divorced and has five grown children. Currently she is getting ready for spring field work. The business was started in 2007 when she received two head of cattle as a gift from her children. The initial capital for her business start-up was 15,000 soms. Now she would like to ask for a loan from Kiva in order to purchase two head of cattle for further reselling. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle for further reselling.

loans.name: Esther Wanjiku

texts.en:
Esther has practised farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last four years.  She is 32 years old, a single mother of one child.  

She was introduced to KADET  LTD by her friend and this will be her third loan.  She repaid all her previous loans well and in good time. She plans to use the loan amount to buy dairy cows.

In future, Esther hopes to become a leading farmer in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: To buy  dairy cows.

loans.name: Hellie Jean

texts.en:
Hellie Jean M. is from the village of El Salvador, Misamis Oriental. She is 46 years old. Hellie Jean is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Hellie Jean owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from making and selling snacks and other delicacies like rice and hot cakes, and banana and sweet potato cues in the local community. Hellie Jean has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Hellie Jean joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hellie Jean is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed like ripe bananas, flour and sugar. This will be the first loan taken out by Hellie Jean from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed like ripe bananas, flour and sugar

loans.name: Botosi Plus Group

texts.en:
Botosi Plus is a Community Bank made up of 29 members whose chairwoman is Rose M.. These members are united for the same goal- to grow their businesses by loans received from Kiva through MFI HOPE DRC. 

Rose sells mushrooms, peanuts and caterpillars. She began her business in 1980. After hard work and good management, she succeeded in making her business thrive thanks to her accumulated profits and different loans she received from HOPE DRC. Rose is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE DRC, having obtained and correctly repaid 9 loans. She will increase her stock of her goods with her next loan by buying mushrooms, peanuts and caterpillars and reselling them at profit. Her business brings in 50 USD of profit each week. Her dream is to someday open a general store in her environment. Rose is 51 years old, widowed, and the mother of 6 children, whose ages vary between 12 and 30 years old. Four of them attend school.

loans.use: to increase the stock of mushrooms, peanuts and caterpillars

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: L. is currently in the business of selling tea. She is a 23-year-old widow with 2 children; both of them go to school. L. borrowed a loan to stock more tea to sell. With the extra profits from her business, she hopes to pay for her children's schooling in the future.

loans.use: purchase more tea to sell

loans.name: Dinara's Group

texts.en:
Dinara U., 47, is the leader of this group. She resides in Tup and is married to a farmer. They have five children, the youngest of whom is nine years old. Since 2007 she has operated a dairy business. Every day Dinara’s cows yield up to nine liters of milk, which she sells for about $0.24 per liter. The original starting capital was 15,000 KGS. The purpose of Dinara’s application for a loan is to purchase more cattle for generating more milk.

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more dairy cows.

loans.name: Cherity

texts.en: Cherity K. 40 years old and she is currently in a business of selling fruits and vegetables. She is married to a soldier and they have six children, only one of whom is not going to school. Her future goal is to open a shop from her profits.

loans.use: to stock more fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Anara's Group

texts.en:
Anara A., 54, is the leader of this group. She is married to a farmer and has five grown children. Her children chose various paths in life; for instance, one is a teacher and another is a customs service officer. Left together with her husband they keep running the business that was started ten years ago. Anara feeds, waters and pastures the cattle.

The couple is very thankful to micro-crediting firms for providing such opportunities for small businesses to survive in the market and prosper. The credit of 4,000 KGS taken in 2000 from a local firm has helped her business take its first humble steps. Since then the monthly income is about $43, which allows covering all operating costs. The purpose of this loan is to purchase a bull-calf for further fattening and reselling. 

          --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a bull-calf.

loans.name: Corona

texts.en:
Corona C. lives in the village of Agusan Canyon, Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. She is 58 years old, married and has two grown children. She makes a living by running a sari-sari (or variety) store where she sells canned goods, snacks, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits to people who live in her community. She has been in this line of work for more than four years and earns about 12,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2008, Corona joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid five previous loans from HSPFI and is applying for a new one to expand her business by buying additional items to sell to her customers. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Merbina

texts.en:
Merbina is from the village of Maular, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old, married and has four adult children. To make a living, Merbina runs a business venture in the food sector selling fish. Merbina has been engaged in her business for 20 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

 Merbina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fish to sell

Merbina is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP with which she will purchase more fish to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Merbina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy a cow to be slaughtered for his business as a butcher

loans.name: Docki

texts.en: E. is currently in business selling alcohol. She is 30 years old, married, with four children and all of them go to school. E. borrowed a loan to stock more alcohol to sell. She hopes to pay for her children in school in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: to stock more alcohol to sell.

loans.name: Kulmai's Group

texts.en:
Kulmai T., 53, is the leader of this group. She is married to a worker in a local state inspection and has four grown children. The younger kids along with her husband help her in preparing fodder for their livestock. Following the example of most of her friends, she took a loan from a local bank and started up her business of cattle breeding. That helped Kulmai to buy her first cow and equipment for work on a small plot of  land that she owns and gradually build a house. Unfortunately, 2,000 soms of monthly income is not enough to purchase the planned five head of livestock. With this purpose, Kulmai turned to Kiva lenders in search of support.

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep.

loans.name: Lilias

texts.en: Lilias S., 32 years old, is currently in business selling fish. Married to a farmer, she has three children, all of whom are schooling. Her future goal is to focus on her children's education.

loans.use: to stock more fish.

loans.name: Rodegunda

texts.en:
Rodegunda C. is from the village of Agusan Canyon, Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. She is 53 years old. Rodegunda is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Rodegunda owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling ready-to-wear clothing like blouses, T-shirts, pants, jeans & also shoes in the local community. Rodegunda has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Rodegunda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rodegunda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 19,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Rodegunda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products like blouses & T-shirts. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Rodegunda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like blouses & T-shirts.

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en: Vestine is a 39-year-old widow who has two children who are 14 and two years old. Her oldest child completed high school but was not financially able to go on to college. Vestine makes a living by selling bananas and a beverage that is popular locally which is called Ubushera. She has been in this line of work for 10 years and has made enough money to feed her family. She is applying for a loan to buy more items to sell to her customers.

loans.use: to buy bananas and a beverage made out of sorghum called Ubushera.

loans.name: Allan

texts.en:
Allan is 43 years old and is a married man with three children. The oldest child is 22 years old. 

Allan is a farmer working in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. He has been growing rice for almost 10 years. Allan earns about 6,000 PHP per month doing this farming.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs. In the future, he hopes to put up a new business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Nene

texts.en: Nene is currently in business selling greens. She is 26 years old, married, with two children and both of them go to school. Nene borrowed a loan to stock more greens to sell. She hopes to pay for her children in school with extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: to stock more greens to sell.

loans.name: Honoré Adohoungbo

texts.fr: Né le 03 Juin 1971 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, Honoré habite le quartier Abogomè à Akpro-Missérété dans le département de l'Ouémé, depuis un an environ. Honoré est marié à Marguerite et a six enfants à charge, dont quatre sont ses propres enfants. Certains des enfants sont scolarisés. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges de la maison. Honoré n'a pas fréquenté l'école, mais a appris le métier de chauffeur. Parallèlement à cette activité, Honoré vend des pièces détachées à Porto-Novo ; ce qui lui permet de se prendre en charge et d'assurer les besoins de sa famille. Honoré achète ses produits à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. En vue d'élever le niveau de son activité et de mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, Honoré sollicite pour la première fois, l'appui financier de ALIDé. Dans l'avenir, Honoré désire étendre beaucoup plus son activité.
texts.en: Born on 3 June 1971 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin, Honoré has lived in the Abogomé area of Akpro-Missérété in the Ouémé department for about one year. He is married to Marguerite and has six children in his care, of whom four are his own. Some of the children are in school. The couple take care of the various household expenses together. Honoré did not attend school, but trained to be a driver. Along with this activity, he sells spare parts in Porto-Novo, which allows him to take care of himself and his family. He buys his goods in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. With the goal of raising the level of his business and better satisfying the demands of his clientele, Honoré is seeking his first loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners). In the future, Honoré hopes to significantly extend his business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Loboko Plus Group

texts.en:
Esperance is a leader of the community bank named “Loboko Plus” which is composed of 16 micro-entrepreneurs united in solidarity to obtain loans from Kiva through the MFI HOPE DRC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Esperance sells women’s clothing and fish and meat at a market located in the eastern area of Kinshasa. She likes her business because it helps her support her family. Currently, through her sales, Esperance makes about $80 per week. Her plans are to use the next loan to purchase some baskets of fish to resell in order to increase her income. 

Esperance is a trustworthy client of the MFI Hope DRC, having four times received and properly repaid loans. She dreams one day of having her own significant working capital. Esperance is 47 years old, married and the mother of five children whose ages vary between 14 and 28. Three of them attend school.

loans.use: to purchase baskets of fish for resale.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Hannah Kabura

texts.en: For the last 20 years, Hannah has worked as a farmer in the town of Ndunyu Njeru. She is 68 years old, single and has one child. She was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and is now applying for her fourth loan. She paid her first three loans on time and will use her new one to buy seeds and fertilizer for her farm.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer for her farm.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary C. is 40 years old and married to a business man. The couple has five children, three of whom are in school. Mary sell fruits and vegetables and is requesting a loan of SDG400 to purchase more produce. Her future goal is to have a big house.

loans.use: to purchase more fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Emmalyn

texts.en:
Emmalyn A. is from the village of Taglimao, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 33 years old. Emmalyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Emmalyn owns & operates a business venture in the food sector butchering and selling meat in the market. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from butchering & selling pork and poultry meat in the market. Emmalyn has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2010, Emmalyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Emmalyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional meat & working capital. Emmalyn is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional pork and poultry meat. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Emmalyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional pork and poultry meat.
