loans.name: Alnie

texts.en:
48-year-old Alnie is a married woman living in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato with her family. She has three children aged 23, 21 and 19. Her husband works as a farmer and driver.

Alnie is also a farmer. She helps her husband grow rice crops. Alnie does her best to keep their farm productive.

Alnie's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes for her business to be stable.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Jean Baptiste

texts.en:
Jean Baptiste is 28 years old and is single. Jean Baptiste has been operating his pub for the past year. This business is well organized and clear. He employs 3 people to help him. Jean Baptiste works from 6am until 10pm every day. He realizes that he lacks equipment to use in his pub that would improve his service.

Jean Baptiste has requested his first loan from Vision Finance Company s.a to expand his business by buying more stock such as beer like primus, amuster and so on. With that expansion, Jean Baptiste hopes to make more profit so that he will be able to buy his own house and save for his future.

loans.use: To purchase more beer for his pub.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia is married with three children and her spouse sells spare parts. She has one dependent and has a family of five people. Her family goal is to send her children to good schools. She lives in Kinubi Hoima and she sells fresh foods which she has been doing for the past 12 years. She started with a capital of 100,000 Ugx however she faces a challenge of stiff competition and foodstuffs that perish quickly. She hopes in future to have a wholesale shop. She is requesting a loan to install power in her house. With any remainder of the loan, she will buy fresh foods for her stall.

loans.use: to install power in her house.

loans.name: Ezekiel

texts.en:
Ezekiel is 40 years old and married to Emily T., a business lady. They have five school-going children aged 14,11, eight, six, and three years old. Ezekiel owns a "posho" (cornmeal) mill in Tulon trading centre in Kapsabet town. It has been in operation for a period of six years with a monthly income of KES. 21,000.

He has taken out a loan of KES.80,000 from KADET LTD, this being his fourth loan after he successfully serviced his previous loans well and in good time. He intends to use this amount to purchase spare parts for the posho mill and buy more maize for the business.  

The profits will be used to educate his children and look after their whole family's welfare. His dreams of his business becoming sustainable in the future.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his "posho" (cornmeal) mill and buy more maize for sale.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose M., 33 years old, is currently in the business of selling fruit & vegetables. Married to a farmer, she has six children. Four of them are schooling, Her future goal is to improve her business.

loans.use: to stock more fruit & vegetables.

loans.name: Donatha

texts.en:
Donatha is 25 years old. She has one child who is three years old so she has not yet begun school. Donatha sells foodstuffs and she has sold them for six years. This business has enabled her to feed her family. She works with her husband in the foodstuff business.

 Donatha is requesting a loan to purchase more foodstuffs and make more profits. She plans to save the profits she hopes to make.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs for resale.

loans.name: Natalina

texts.en: Natalina is currently in business selling fish. She is 32 years old, married, with four children and three of them go to school. Natalina borrowed a loan to stock more fish to sell. She hopes to build a house in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: to stock more fish to sell.

loans.name: Kyanzaire_Hiv/aids Tweyambe, Bushenyi Group

texts.en: A. Oscar is the leader of Kyanzaire_Hiv/Aids Tweyambe, Bushenyi. He is 34 years old and married with one child. He is in the business of selling produce like beans, millet, and coffee. He operates from Kasheshero Town selling mostly to town dwellers and he is able to make 100,000/= as weekly profits. He has been in the business for five years after working for someone else until he fulfilled his dream of becoming self-employed. His dream is to be able to construct his own store so that he can stop renting. He needs a loan to be able to buy more produce (cereals) for resale.

loans.use: To buy more produce (cereals) for resale.

loans.name: James Matheri

texts.en:
James has practised farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 21 years.  He is 52 years old, married to Mary Wanjiru, and they have five children.  

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his sixth loan.  He repaid all his previous loans well and in good time.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy seeds and fertilizer.

In future, James hopes to become a leading farmer in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en:
Mary Jean M. is from the village of Taglimao, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 31 years old. Mary Jean is widowed and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Jean owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling  canned goods, snack foods & biscuits. She also buys and sells gold dust in the local community. Mary Jean has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mary Jean joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jean has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Mary Jean is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional gold dust & snack foods for her store. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Mary Jean from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional gold dust & snack foods for her store.

location.town: Taglimao, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Emmaneul

texts.en:
Emmanuel is a 29-year-old man. He is single and has adopted an orphan.
He has been a motorbike taxi driver for one year. He transports people from 5 am until 11 pm. He currently has to rent a motorbike. 
Emmanuel has requested a loan from Kiva Lenders and Vision Finance Company in order to purchase his own motorbike.
Emmanuel will use the profits from his motorbike taxi to help his family and build a house.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy tires

loans.name: David Muchiri

texts.en:
David has practised farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 21 years.  He is 39 years old, married to Margaret Wangui, and they have five children.  

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his fifth loan.  He paid all of his previous loans well and in good time.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy seeds and fertilizer.

In the future, David hopes to become a leading farmer in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Fondation Plus Group

texts.en:
Odette, right, is the chairwoman of the Community Bank named “Fondation Plus” which is composed of 11 members united in solidarity for receiving Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses.

Odette, 59, became a micro-entrepreneur in 1980. She manages her own general store in the East of Kinshasa. She works hard with good management skills in order to realize her dream of one day opening a larger store in her area. Her business generates a profit of US$90 per week. Odette is a trust-worthy client of the MFI HOPE RDC, having five times received and correctly repaid loans. She will increase her stock of merchandise with her next loan by purchasing, soaps, vegetable oil, sacks of rice and reselling them at a profit. Odette is a widow and the mother of eight children aged between 32 and 41 years old. All of them are independent.

loans.use: to increase the store’s stock by buying soaps, vegetable oil, and sacks of rice to resell at profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Doru

texts.en: Doru C. is 30 years old. Currently she is in a business selling food. Married to a businessman, they have three children all of them in school. Her future goal is to open a big shop.

loans.use: to stock more food.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita earns a living through farming. She grows rice that she sells to the market. Anita earns about 6,000 PHP from this farming. She also grows pigs for fattening and sale. Anita works hard to provide for her family. She plans to use her loan to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers and seeds.

Anita is married and has six children. She wishes for her family's living conditions to improve.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a resident of Muranga in Central Kenya and has been in farming for over 20 years. His farm produces pigs and pork for the local market. He is married with 7 children, all adults.

Peter has requested a loan of 60,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase piglets and their feed. He says his large-scale poultry business will have a big boost and improve his income a great deal for the family good.

Peter says the cost of feed has gone up, posing a challenge to the business. He adds that Juhudi loans have made farming easier for farmers.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Kemara

texts.en: Kemara is currently in a business selling rice and millet. She is 32 years old, married with six children — all of them in school. Kemara took out a loan to stock more rice and millet to sell. She hopes to open a shop in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: Stock more rice and millet to sell.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn Z. is from the village of Agusan Canyon, Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. She is 53 years old. Evelyn is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Evelyn owns and operates a business buying and selling health and generic medicinal products. She also buys and sells curtains, pillow cases and blankets. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17000 PHP from HSPFI and is requesting a new loan of 23000 PHP to purchase additional generic drugs and blankets. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Evelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Theogene

texts.en: Theogene is 38 years old. He is not married and he is hardworking. Theogene sells timber, and he has sold timber for 3 years. This business has enabled him look after his family. He is requesting a loan to buy more timber and hence make more profits. He plans make savings and later on purchase cattle for sale.

loans.use: to buy timber for resale

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 36 years old and is married with two children aged between 5 and 6. He has been a motorbike taxi driver for 1 year. He transports people every day from 6am until 10pm.

Emmanuel has requested a loan from Kiva lenders to buy a motorbike. With the profit generated, he will pay his children's school fees and save for his future.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Ayozu

texts.en: Ayozu Cathernien is 28 years old and is currently in the business of running a food market. She is married to a student, and they have two children, all of whom  are getting schooling. Her future goal is to take care about her children's education costs.

loans.use: stock more food in the market for resale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Makhavat's Group

texts.en:
Makhavat I., 40, is the leader of this group. She resides in Tup, of northern Kyrgyzstan, and is married to a construction worker and has four children. The oldest daughter is a college student, while the son found employment in Moscow, and the youngest two go to school. 

In his free time her husband works in the field, while Makhavat herself has been running a dairy business for almost ten years now. Every morning she yields 8 to 9 liters of milk, which she sells for 11 soms per liter. Along with it she currently is getting ready for spring field working. A monthly income of 3 000 soms does not allow for savings and it is not a big enoungh amount of funds in order to construct a house. 

The story of this entrepreneur started in 2001, when she sold the livestock she owned and started cultivating land, and this year she received a rich harvest. The purpose of the loan is a purchase of a tonne of potato seeds and lubrications and fuel for the farming equipment. She hopes to get a rich harvest this year too. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase potato seeds and fuel

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
Chona B. is from the village of Iponan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 42 years old. Chona is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Chona owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, shampoo, soap & biscuits in the local community. Her husband is providing motorela (moto-taxi) or habal-habal service. Chona has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Chona joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Chona has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Chona is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & beverages for the retail store. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Chona from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Harriette is 32 years old. She is married. She sells clothes and has been in this business for one year. She has one employee and works daily from 7am until 8pm.

Harriette has requested a loan from Kiva lenders to purchase more clothes to sell. With her additional profits, Harriette will reinvest in her business and save for her future.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet B. is from the village of Santo Niño, Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. She is 29 years old. Janet is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Janet owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, detergents, instant noodles, shampoo, soap & biscuits in the local community. Janet has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Janet joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Janet has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Janet is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, detergents & beverages. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Janet from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her  business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, detergents & beverages to sell

loans.name: Kezeroni

texts.en: Kezeroni is a 38-year-old married man with seven children, and he owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in a retail shop for a year, and the business is promising, as he has been able to get income to cater the family basics. His hardship is delays in supply delivery, and his vision is to have a wholesale shop, buy a plot in town, and educate his children. Kezeroni intends to use the loan to buy sugar and soap for selling.

loans.use: to buy sugar and soap for resale

loans.name: Pauline

texts.fr: Pauline est née en 1957 au Bénin et vit depuis quinze ans environs à Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. C'est une veuve et mère de huit enfants, tous scolarisés, mais qui ne sont pus à a charge. Pauline vit donc seule et assure ses différents besoins. Pauline n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de sa famille, Pauline mène comme activité la vente d'huile à moteur, de gasoil et aussi de maïs par le système de distribution. Pauline achète ses produits auprès des grossistes. Pauline est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse ses crédits. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de satisfaire sa clientèle, Pauline sollicite encore une fois l'aide financier de ALIDé. Son ambition est de renforcer davantage son activité afin d'accroître son revenu.
texts.en: Pauline was born in 1957 in Benin and has lived for about fifteen years in Agblangandan in the town of Sèmè-Podji. She is a widow and has eight children, all of whom are in school, but none of whom are in her care. Pauline thus lives alone and provides for herself. She never attended school. To meet her needs and those of her family, Pauline runs a business selling motor oil, fuel oil, and also maize through the local distribution system. She buys her goods from wholesalers and is a longstanding client of ALIDÉ who has repaid all her loans. With the goal of strengthening her business and satisfying her clientele, Pauline is seeking another loan with ALIDÉ. Her ambition is to further strengthen her business in order to increase her income.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize and cans of motor oil

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan is currently in the business of selling clothes. She is 46 years old, married, with 7 children, and all of them go to school. Susan borrowed a loan to stock more clothes to sell. She hopes to build a house in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: stock more clothes to sell

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 31 years old and is married. He owns a motorcycle transportation business. This business is open daily from 6am until 10pm. His business is well-organized.
Daniel has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to buy essential materials for his motorcycle. With the profit, he plans to reinvest in his business and to save for his future.

loans.use: To buy essential material for his motorcycle business

loans.name: Selina

texts.en: Selina A. is 38 years old and is currently in the business of selling alcoholic beverages. She is married to a farmer, and they have five children in school. Her future goal is to take care of her children's educations.

loans.use: stock more alcoholic beverages for resale

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is a 46-year-old married man with six children. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the retail shop for two years, in which he started with 500,000 shillings and now has 3,500,000 shillings. His vision is to be in the wholesale business and a keep a self-sustainable, developed family. Stephen intends to use the credit to buy salt, soap and cooking oil for selling.

loans.use: to buy salt, soap and cooking oil for selling

loans.name: Katebo Basooka Kwavula Group

texts.en: 38-year-old N. Anet is affiliated with Katebo Basooka Kwavula group and has been a fish monger for the past decade in Katebo-Mpigi. Anet, a single mother of 4, was previously doing subsistence farming. She now mostly does commercial farming as a means of supplementing on her profits. Anet says she envisions better prospects for her business in the coming future as long as she continues with her diligence-driven attitude that she uses in her business. Weekly, she says this business generates shillings of 60,000 as profit. She says with this loan, she wants to purchase more fish to resell.

loans.use: to purchase of more fish to resell

loans.name: Teimuraz

texts.en:
Teimuraz G. lives in the village of Dzalisi, Kartli region. He is 54 years old and lives with his wife, Tsisana. Teimuraz and Tsisana are actively involved in agricultural activities. They have three milk cows and sell dairy products locally. Also, Teimuraz has a shop of construction materials. The main product sold in the shop is cement. The total income of the family is 800 laris per month. 

With one part of the requested loan, Teimuraz plans to cultivate a plot of land and sow maize. The harvested corn will be sold locally. With the other part of the credit, Teimuraz will increase stock-in-trade in his shop. It will ensure flow of additional customers to the shop. In the future, Teimuraz plans to make some savings and invest in the further development of the dairy farm.

loans.use: to pay for a tractor for the cultivation of his land and to increase the stock-in-trade of his shop.

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en: Godfrey is a 32-year-old married man with two children, and he owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been dealing in produce and selling video and football shows for eight years. He started buying produce on a small scale and now buys on large scale, and he has rennovated his cinema hall. His hardships are price fluctuations and providing shade for his inventory, and his vision is a well-established produce store and an educated family. Godfrey needs the loan to buy maize for selling.

loans.use: to buy maize to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is currently in the business of selling biscuits and sugar. She is 37 years old, married, with 7 children, and all of them go to school. Mary borrowed a loan to stock more biscuits and sugar to sell. She hopes to open up a big shop in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: to stock more biscuits and sugar to sell

loans.name: Jenty

texts.en: Jenty P. is 35 years old. She is currently in the business of a food market. She is married to a soldier, and they have five children. Three of them are receiving schooling. Her future goal is to build a house for rent.

loans.use: stock more foods int the market for resale

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a married woman with six children. Five attend school while one is still too young for school. They live at a house that they own, but it does not have electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children. 

For the past eight years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She cooks beans, chapati, and rice, and sells at a profit, which has enabled her to provide her family with basic needs. Mwanajuma dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000, she is requesting to purchase 3 bundles of wheat flour, a gallon of cooking oil, salt and 10 kilograms of sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase 3 bundles of wheat flour, a gallon of cooking oil, salt and 10 kilograms of sugar

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily C. is from the village of Thailand, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 41 years old. Emily is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Emily owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling canned goods, junk foods, beverages, shampoo, soap, and biscuits in the local community. Emily has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Emily joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emily has successfully repaid a previous loan of 23000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Emily is requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products like canned goods, beverages & detergents. This loan will be the 9th loan taken out by Emily from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, beverages & detergents

loans.name: Lorn

texts.en:
Lorn was born in 1955. He is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land, on which he grows rice to sell as well as to feed his own family. 

His wife, Phal, is presented in the picture with him. She owns a general store in a nearby village, where she sells groceries to help support the family. Lorn is the father of four children. One is a fisherman, another helps his mother in her business, and the others study at a local public school. 

Lorn's rice field is far away from the irrigation system, so to improve his product, Mr. Lorn is seeking a loan to buy gasoline to transport water to the field. He will use the rest of the loan to hire farming laborers to help him farm.

loans.use: To buy gasoline to transport water to his rice field.

loans.name: Husam

texts.en: Husam A. K., 21 years old, has graduated from high school but was not able to enter a college for some financiA. reasons. That didn’t stop him though – he decided to take technician courses and training. Husam is now an air conditioning and cooling technician. He works for a company of good repute and handles a few projects by himself, but that is not enough for him. He is now applying for a loan to buy his own tools and start his own business as an air conditioning and cooling technician.

loans.use: to buy his own tools and start his own business as an air conditioning and cooling technician.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty G. is 30 years old. She is married to a farmer. Together they have three children, one of whom goes to school.

Betty currently has a business selling food. Her future goal is to take care of her children and provide them with more education.

loans.use: stock more food to sell.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 42 years old and married to a teacher. She has six children and all of them go to school. 

Grace currently has a business selling ice cream. She is requesting a loan to stock more ice cream to sell. She hopes to build a concrete house in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: stock more ice cream to sell.

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Annie is a 33-year-old farmer who lives in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She tills her land and prepares it well for cropping. She grows rice and sells her harvest to the market. Annie is planning to grow pigs in her backyard. She says the extra income will really help her family.

Annie's loan will be used to purchase fertilizer, piglets and feed. She hopes for her ventures to prosper.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, piglets and feed

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane P. is 30 years old. She is married to a farmer. They have three children, one of whom goes to school. 

Jane currently runs a business selling food at market. Her goal is to take good care of her children's future.

loans.use: stock more food to sell at market.

loans.name: Evaliste

texts.fr: Evaliste N. est salarié, et client d’ACB depuis 2007.  Il a 53 ans, il est marié, né au Rwanda, et il a 4 enfants entre 6 an et 18 ans.  4 de ses enfants va à l’école, et Evariste a fini 3 ans d’école poste-primaire.  Ce crédit est son 10 eme cycle avec ACB, et il va utiliser son prêt pour payer les frais scolaires pour ses enfants.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est de cultiver les mais en augmentant l’espace de cultiver.  Il voudrait s’autofinancer, et aussi éduquer ses enfants jusqu’à un niveau universitaire.
texts.en: Evaliste N. is a salaried employee and has been a client of ACB (one of Kiva's field partners) since 2007. He is 53 years old, married, was born in Rwanda, and has four children, who are between 6 and 18 years old. Four of his children attend school, and Evaliste completed 3 years of post-primary school. This loan is his 10th cycle with ACB, and he is going to use it to pay for his children's school fees. His strategy to raise his business is to cultivate maize and increase his farming land. He would like to be self-financing, and also to educate his children through the university level.

loans.use: to pay for his children's school fees

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie B. is from the village of Thailand, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 46 years old. Rosemarie is separated from her spouse and has three school-aged children. 

To make a living, Rosemarie runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, candies, shampoo, soap, and biscuits to the local community. Rosemarie has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 16,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2008, Rosemarie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosemarie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 23,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. 

Rosemarie is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, detergents, and beverages. This loan will be the 13th loan taken out by Rosemarie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, detergents, and beverages to sell.

loans.name: Otgonbayar

texts.en:
Mrs.Otgonbayar S., 43, is married and has five children. They live in Darkhan, the second largest city in Mongolia. Her family owns a plot of land and a small house on it. Her youngest three children attend a secondary school. Her husband works in a secondary school as a watchman.

In 2002 Otgonbayar opened a small grocery kiosk near her home. After four years (2007) she managed to build a small shop and obtained permission to run a grocery store. Her business is expanding gradually, showing her ability and character as a businesswoman. She buys her products from local wholesale dealers and sells them to local customers. She has a good reputation in her neighborhood.

The loan Otgonbayar is taking now will be used to buy necessary building materials to renovate her house and shop. She is planning to do some exterior work on the family house and her shop by fixing the roof and plastering and painting the walls.

loans.use: To buy materials for exterior renovation of her house and store

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana is 42 years old and is a married woman with five children. Her oldest child is 22 years old and the youngest is 14. Her husband works as a farmer and a school guard.

Diana is also a farmer, helping her husband maintain their rice farm. Diana and her husband have been growing rice for 20 years. She said that they usually earn about 8,500 PHP doing this farming.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs. In the future, Diana hopes to put up a new business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary J. is 29 years old, married and has three children, all of whom go to school. She currently sells ice cream.

Mary took a loan to stock more ice cream to sell. She hopes to open up a big shop in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: To stock more Ice cream to sell

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie P. is 41 years old, married and has two school-aged children. She is from the municipality of Eastern Wao, Lanao del Sur province on the Mindanao islands. Elvie owns a store from which she buys and sells seafood products including fish like sardines, milkfish and shrimp to the local community. Elvie has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Elvie joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Elvie has successfully repaid a previous loan, her seventh from HSPFI, of 17,000 PHP. Her previous loan was used to purchase additional fish and for some working capital. Elvie is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish like mackerel, sardines and milkfish. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish like mackerel, sardines and milkfish

loans.name: Radia

texts.en:
Radia Y. is a 35-year-old, married woman. She and her husband have three children, two of whom currently attend school. Her husband is a farmer.

To earn a living, she sells fruits and vegetables. She is seeking a loan to increase her stock of fruits and vegetables. Her future goal is to be able to pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase additional fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional goods for his retail shop and bar

loans.name: Toimasi

texts.en:
Toimasi A. is a 39-year-old, married man. His wife, Lydia L., is a social worker. They are blessed with three children who attend school. He has been running a spare parts shop for one year and typically earns a monthly income of approximately 5,000 KES.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by a staff member, and this is the first loan he has sought from KADET. He plans to use the loan proceeds to buy more spare parts for re-sale purposes. The profits he anticipates will be generated as a result of the loan will used to open another shop in Kajiado town. In the future Toimasi hopes to grow his business and to start a transport company.

loans.use: To purchase additional spare parts

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is a 35-year-old, married woman. She and her husband have two children, both of whom go to school.

To earn a living, she operates an ice cream sales business. Christine is seeking a loan to stock more ice cream to sell to her customers. In the future, she hopes to open up a shop with additional profits from her business.

loans.use: To increase her stock of ice cream

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy S. is a 47-year-old, married woman from the village of Thailand, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She and her husband have four adult-age children. To earn a living, Lucy owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. Specifically, she runs a sari-sari (variety) shop, and her primary source of income is derived from buying and selling canned goods, junk food, beverages, shampoo, soap, and biscuits in the local community. Lucy has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2008, Lucy joined HSPFI to gain much-needed access to financial services. As a result, she was better able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve her family's standard of living. Recently, Lucy successfully repaid a loan in the amount of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital purposes. Lucy is now requesting a new loan, this time in the amount of 20,000 PHP ($475), which will be used to purchase additional products like canned goods, junk food, and beverages. Notably, this loan would be the sixth loan taken out by Lucy from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional products such as canned goods, junk food, and beverages

loans.name: Chantal

texts.en:
Greetings from Chantal in her beauty salon in Kimironko, Rwanda. Chantal is 26 years old and married. She has adopted three orphans.

Chantal, who has been in this business for two years, also works in the African Library. In addition to that, her salon business in Kigali attracts many working-class clients. She employs three people in her salon. She is open from 8am until 7pm every day. One of the challenges in her business is not having enough equipment in the hair salon, especially for her women clients.

Chantal has requested a loan from Kiva lenders to purchase more essential materials for her beauty salon. With this profit, Chantal will reinvest in her business and save for her future.

loans.use: To purchase essentials for her beauty salon

loans.name: Busililka

texts.en:
Busililka N. is 26 years old, married and has three children who all go to school.

Busililka sells milk. She borrowed a loan to stock more milk to sell.

She hopes in the future to build a concrete house with the extra profits from her business.

loans.use: To stock more milk to sell

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong S., a 61-year-old married woman living in the province of Kompong Cham, has spent her life cultivating crops, a skill she learned from her grandparents when she was young. Her husband also works in the farm fields frequently alongside her. Kong's three children, all married, are employed in a variety of occupations and contribute income to her to help support the family’s needs.  In order to make additional profit, Kong will use her loan to buy some iron to sell in the busy market.

loans.use: to buy some iron to sell.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia C. is 56 years old, married and has eight adult-aged children. She is from Manila Group barangay in the municipality of Wao, Lanao del Sur province on the Mindano islands. Alicia operates a store where she sells primarily vegetables and spices like ginger, onions and garlic to the local community. Alicia has been in business for over six years and earns approximately 14,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Alicia joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Alicia successfully repaid her previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional inventory and gain some working capital.

Alicia is requesting a new loan, her fifth from HSPFI, of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional vegetables like cabbages, eggplants and red bell peppers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional vegetables like cabbages, eggplants and red bell peppers

location.town: Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur

loans.name: Dorita

texts.en:
Dorita is a 55-year-old married woman who lives in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato with her family. She is married to a farmer. Dorita is also engaged in farming. She helps her husband grow and sell rice. Dorita also manages their sari-sari store where she sells items like cookies, chips and other kinds of products.

Dorita has requested a loan to purchase fertilizer and additional store items to sell.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and additional store items to sell

loans.name: Sejerina

texts.en: Sejerina P. is 30 years old and currently in a business of selling food. She is married to a farmer and they have three children, two of them in school. Her future goal is to pay for all her children's school fees.

loans.use: to stock more food to sell.

loans.name: Mrs. Him Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of fifteen people. Mrs. Him is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. Each member’s portion of the loan will be used for different purpoS. in order to improve their family’s standard of living. 

Mrs. Him is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she grows rice for her own family and to sell. She is also a chicken breeder. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. So, Mrs. Him is seeking a loan to buy more chickens. She will use the rest of the loan  to buy some piglets for breeding in order to start a new business. 

She was born in 1971. She is a widow with two children: one is a construction worker and the other is studying at the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more chickens

loans.name: Biasha

texts.en:
Biasha is a married woman with one child still too young for school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For the past two years, she has operated a tailoring business. In addition, she has also incorporated a dressmaking school and a bicycle spare parts shop which contribute to her income. 

Biasha sells to her neighbours and to the parents of school children. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business since during rainy season it becomes difficult to operate in her area leading to low customer turnout. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she is requesting, she wants to purchase sewing threads, pins, cloth materials and printed rollers for her tailoring business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sewing threads, pins, cloth materials, and printed rollers for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana N. is 35 years old and currently in a business selling alcohol. Married to a soldier, they have three children unfortunately none of them in school. Her future goal is to build a house.

loans.use: to stock more alcohol.

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Carolina M. is from the village of Extension, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 34 years old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Carolina owns a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Carolina has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Carolina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from HSPFI and is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP to purchase additional inventory. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Carolina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods and beverages

loans.name: Ronelyn

texts.en:
Ronelyn S. is 35 years old, married and has four school-aged children. She is from the village of Eastern Wao, Lanao del Sur province in the Mindanao islands. Ronelyn buys and sells electronic products, hair accessories, wallets and DVD’s to the local community. Ronelyn has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Ronelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid her previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional inventory and gain some working capital. Ronelyn is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, her sixth from HSPFI, which will be used to purchase additional items like cellphones and more hair accessories. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional items like cellphones and hair accessories

loans.name: Ainura Kyisaeva's Group

texts.en:
Ainura K. is 47 and married with two sons and two daughters. Her daughters study at school and her sons are farmers. Ainura is the leader of this group.

Fourteen years ago Ainura’s sister suggested she breed livestock to make additional money. Since that time she has been doing so. She started with an initial investment of 2,000 KGS, and now she earns 3,000 KGS per month. This profit made it possible for her to improve her living conditions and purchase a DVD player and a TV.

With money received from her loan Ainura would like to purchase more livestock for breeding. In the future she wants to build a house for her sons.

About Mol Bulak Finance

This loan is being presented by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious, socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of its “3-Ps” concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow larger) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.

To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team—Supporters of Kyrgyzstan—at: http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Mrs. Phorn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Sixteen people make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Phorn is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. Each member’s portion of the loan will be used for different purposes in order to improve their family’s standard of living. 

Mrs. Phorn is a chicken breeder and a farmer who owns a plot of land where she can grow rice for her own family. Her husband, Mr. Bun Ly, is a construction worker and an iron welder. Since her husband’s business is going well, he wants to expand. So, Mrs. Phorn is applying for a loan to buy more iron welding machinery. 

She was born in 1983. This couple has two children who are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more iron welding machinery

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 27 years old and is single. He is a taxi driver with 3 years experience. He transports people every day from 8am until 10pm and he employs one person to help him.

David has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to buy essential materials for his taxi. With the profit, he will build his own house and save for his future.

loans.use: To buy essential material for his taxi.

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda is from the village of Canubay, Oroquieta City. She is 33 years old, married and has four children. To make a living, Nilda runs a business venture in the retail sector operating a general store. 

Nilda earns approximately 6,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. Nilda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC.

Nilda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP with which she will  purchase a variety of products such as shampoo, can goods etc. . This will be the second loan taken out by Nilda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of products such as shampoo, can goods etc.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 49-year-old married man living with his wife and two young children. He is from Lebanon. He's owned his shop since 1983, selling music CDs and video tapes. In addition, he sells mobiles pre-paid cards. He struggles with lack of financial capital. So today, he is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase additional products. By doing this, he should be able to increase his income and overcome the difficulties in improving himself and strengthening his business.

loans.use: to purchase additional products.

loans.name: Emelita

texts.en: Emelita M. is from the village of Eastern, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 38 years old. Emelita is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Emelita operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling fruits like apples, oranges, guava and mangoes in the local community. Emelita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 12,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. In 2009, Emelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Emelita is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fruits like watermelons and apples. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Emelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fruits like watermelons and apples.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan K. is 35 years old. She is currently in a business of selling fish. She is married to a driver and they have four children; only one goes to school. Her future goal is to build a house.

loans.use: to stock more fish.

loans.use: to buy retail commodities to resell

loans.name: Rizalyn

texts.en:
Rizalyn M. is from the village of Eastern, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 31 years old. Rizalyn is married and has three school-aged children. Rizalyn owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling rice and corn in the local community. Rizalyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2009, Rizalyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. She has successfully repaid her last loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to purchase additional inventory & as working capital. 

This loan will be her fifth from HSPFI. Rizalyn is requesting 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional rice & corn. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI: 

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is married to a farmer with three children — two girls and one boy who all attend school. Amina and the family live at a house that they own. It does not have electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past three years, she has operated a farming business, planting maize for sale. She also operates a khanga (cloth) business that contributes to her other source of income. She operates at the market and from home, selling to neighbors. Amina faces a major challenge of seasonality. During the rainy season, transportation of goods becomes difficult in her area of operation. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings she is requesting she wants to purchase fertilizers and seedlings for her farm and add bales of khangas for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans and educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seedlings for her farm and add bales of khangas (cloth) for resale.

loans.name: Vong

texts.en:
Vong K., age 41, makes a living by selling fish. She sells the fish that her husband gives her or that she buys from other fishermen. She currently earns an average of US$2 a day. She has been running her business for years. Her husband is 41 years old and is a fisherman who works along a local river. Vong K. is the mother of three children: two are married and one is single. 

As well as fish selling, she has always grown different kinds of vegetables on her own land for extra income. Unfortunately, her vegetable crops are not growing well because it was too dry at the start of this year and this may influence her crop. She faces a difficult season if she is not able to irrigate her crop. Vong K. is taking a loan to purchase a water pump for her vegetable crops. With the rest of the funds, she will buy a cart horse for her son who does not yet have a job.

loans.use: to purchase a water pump for her vegetable crops and to buy a cart horse for her son.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to stock more food at her market

loans.name: Mrs. Sopheap Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap is a village bank president who has been selected by the fourteen members who make up this village bank loan. Each member’s portion of the loan will be used for different purposes in order to improve their family’s standard of living. 

Mrs. Sopheap is a tailor who can make some profit with which to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Soeun, is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land where he grows rice to support his family and to sell. Although they both work, they earn a small income. To improve this condition, Mrs. Sopheap would like to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business. 

She was born in 1970. She is the mother of four children who are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Genewyn

texts.en:
Genewyn C. is from the village of Eastern, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 28 years old, married, and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Genewyn owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, junk food, beverages, biscuits, shampoo, soap & detergent in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Genewyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to purchase additional inventory & as working capital. She is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, junk food & instant noodles. This will be Genewyn’s 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, junk food & instant noodles

loans.name: Abdurashid

texts.ru: Асроров Абдурашид проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 32 года. Женат. Имеет одного ребенка. Жена занимается шитьем национальных платьев. Сам Абдурашид предоставляет услугу, такси. Он в основном развозит людей. В этой области он имеет богатый опыт. Целью кредита является ремонт автомашины и приобретения швейной машинки для жены.
texts.en: Abdurashid A. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda.  He is 32 years old, married, and has one child. His wife works sewing traditional dresses. Abdurashid runs a taxi service.  He has vast experience in this.  He is taking out a loan to repair his car and to buy a sewing machine for his wife.

loans.use: to repair his car and to buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Mery

texts.en: Mery J. is 40 years old.  She is married to a carpenter, and the couple have one child who is not yet in school. She is currently in the business of selling fruits & vegetables.  Her future goal is to build a house.

loans.use: to stock more furits & vegetables

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline is currently in the business of selling clothes. She is 28 years old, married, and has 4 children, all of whom go to school. She has requested a loan to stock more clothes to sell. She hopes to build a house for rent in the future with the extra profits from her business.

loans.use: to stock more clothes to sell

loans.name: Jenifa

texts.en: Jenifa A. is 40 years old.  She is married to a farmer, and the couple have five children, three of whom are in school.  She is currently in the business of selling fruits & vegetables.  Her future goal is to pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: to stock more fruits & vegetables

loans.name: Omer

texts.fr: Né le 03 décembre 1972 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, Omer vit depuis dix ans à Finagnon un quartier de Cotonou. Omer est marié à Aïtcha une revendeuse, et a sept enfants, tous scolarisés. Omer assure ensemble avec sa femme les différentes charges de la maison. Omer a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Pour nourrir sa famille et satisfaire ses besoins quotidiens, Omer achète à Dantopka, marché international du Bénin, des cartons de poissons et d'ailerons qu'il revend à son domicile depuis cinq ans. Ce premier prêt permettra certainement à Omer de rehausser le niveau de son activité et d’accroître sa clientèle et son revenu.
texts.en: Born on 3 December 1972 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Omer has lived in Finagnon, an area of Cotonou, for ten years. He is married to Aïtcha, a retailer, and has seven children, all of whom are in school. Together with his wife, Omer takes care of the family's expenses. He ended his studies at the secondary level. For the past five years, in order to feed his family and meet his daily needs, Omer has been going to Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, to buy boxes of fish and poultry wings that he re-sells at his home. This first loan will definitely allow him to raise the level of his business and increase his clientele and income.

loans.use: To buy boxes of fish and poultry wings

loans.name: Jazira's Group

texts.en:
Jazira B. is the leader of this group. She is 30 and married to a private entrepreneur. She has a daughter and a son, both of whom are preschool age (under seven).  In order to earn additional money to meet her family’s needs, Jazira started breeding livestock eight years ago with an initial investment of 4000 soms. By reselling her livestock after fattening them, she earns an additional 10,000 soms per month.  She has requested this loan because she needs money to purchase more livestock for further reselling. In the near future Jazira wants to increase her business’ revenue, and then in the autumn she plans to purchase a truck.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.  MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (remaining environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.   If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma G. is from the village of Poblacion 2, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 30 years old, married, and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Wilma owns & operates a bakeshop. The main source of income for the business comes from baking & selling a variety of confectionaries such as cookies and cakes in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Wilma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to purchase additional ingredients & as working capital. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional cooking ingredients like flour, eggs & sugar. This will be Wilma’s 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Pol

texts.en:
Pol S. earns a living by raising pigs in a pigpen behind her house in Baray district of Kompong Tom province. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. In addition, she also assists her husband to provide a rice-milling service to their neighbors. 

The couple has four children; one is already married and lives away from the family home while the other three are single. Two of their kids are working, one is a construction worker and the other is a bus driver. In order to earn extra income, Pol S. will be using the loan to buy more pig-feed and piglets to raise.

loans.use: to buy more pig-feed and piglets to raise.

loans.name: Béatrice

texts.fr: Née en 1976 au Bénin, Béatrice vit depuis cinq ans à Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Béatrice est mariée à Marcellin, un policier, et est mère de quatre enfants tous scolarisés. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges de la maison. Béatrice n'a jamais été à l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et assurer les besoins de sa famille, Béatrice vend depuis sept ans environ, divers produits (conserves de tomates, lait, petit pois, savons, oeufs, sucre, allumettes, dentifrices, etc.). Béatrice achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et les revend à son domicile. En vue de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, Béatrice sollicite pour la première fois, l'appui financier de ALIDé. Dans l'avenir, Béatrice désire renforcer son capital et élargir davantage le niveau de son activité
texts.en: Born in 1976 in Benin, Béatrice has lived for five years in Agblangandan in the town of Sèmè-Podji. She is married to Marcellin, a policeman, and is the mother of four children, all of whom are in school. The couple take care of the various household expenses together. Béatrice never attended school. To meet her needs and those of her family, Béatrice has been selling various items (canned tomatoes, milk, peas, soap, eggs, sugar, matches, toothpaste, etc.). She buys her goods at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, and re-sells them at her home. With the goal of satisfying her customers' demands, Béatrice is seeking her first loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners). In the future, Béatrice wants to strengthen her capital and further enlarge the scale of her business.

loans.use: To buy various goods (canned goods, milk, soap, eggs, sugar, etc.)

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Paulina is currently in the business of selling soft drinks. She is 25 years old, married, and has three children, two of whom go to school. Paulina took out a loan to stock more soft drinks to sell. She hopes to pay her children's school fees in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: to stock more soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Gakuweebwa Munno Development Group

texts.en:
J. Simon, 29, has been in the motorcycle transportation business for four years now in Buswabulongo-Mityana. He says he began with somebody else's motorbike before he at length got his own. Simon, who is happily married and has one child, says through the course of these years he has learnt certain virtues like civility, punctuality and being humane, which he says have made him strike up a good rapport with new and old clients alike. 

In the course of time, he has also made headway in consolidating his profits. Besides banking on earnings from this business, he also does pig husbandry. Simon, who makes common cause with Gakuweebwa Munno Development Group, says he is going to use proceeds from this loan to purchase more piglets that he will resell when they are mature.

loans.use: to purchase piglets to resell when they are mature

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba G. is married and has three children.  She buys fish from the market, smokes them at her house, and sells them near Abura.  She has been doing this for 7 years. Her husband works in construction.  Aba uses her income to supports her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  Aba will use the loan to purchase more fresh fish to smoke for resale.

loans.use: purchase fish to smoke and sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty T. is 30 years old.  She is currently in the business of selling food.  She is married to a farmer and they have three children, all of whom are in school.  Her future goal is to buy more goods.

loans.use: stock more food

loans.name: Achola

texts.en: Achola is currently in the business of selling cakes. She is 28 years old, married and has 2 children, 1 of whom goes to school. Achola borrowed a loan to stock more cakes to sell. She hopes to build a rental house in the future with the extra profits from her business.

loans.use: stock more cakes to sell

loans.name: Vahan

texts.en:
Vahan H. is 54 years old. He lives in Vanadzor city with his wife and his school-aged son. Vahan’s daughter is married and lives separately. 

Twelve years ago, Vahan re-equipped his garage into a workshop where he runs his business: Vahan makes windscreens to order.  He purchases glass and other necessary materials from wholesale importers.  With his business income Vahan is able to provide for his family.

Vahan is seeking a loan of 800,000 AMD to buy glass and plastic films for his business.

loans.use: buy glass and plastic films for his business

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn D. is from the village of Kalawaig, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 35 years old, is married, and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Merlyn owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap & biscuits in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 12000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Merlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & fund working capital. 

Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & beverages to sell. This loan will be her 5th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchase canned goods, snack foods & beverages to resell

loans.name: Louch

texts.en: Louch P. is a 38-year-old farmer and mother. She was blessed with five kids, four of whom are attending the public school while one is already married. Louch P. has been working in the farming business for many years. She inherited farmland from her grandmother, where she grows different kinds of crops. She has a life partner in her husband who is a horse and cart driver. Louch P.’s husband uses his own horse and cart to run a taxi service, picking up merchandise and people who want to go anywhere in and around Kompong Cham province. Presently, his cart horse is getting old. He really wants to buy a new one. To do this, Louch P. would like to ask for a loan to buy a cart horse to replace the old one for her husband. She hopes to use the rest of the funds to buy a new horse as well.

loans.use: to buy a cart horse and a new horse.

loans.name: Nona

texts.en:
Nona B. lives in the village of Tokhliauri, Kakheti Region. Nona is 44 years old. She lives with her husband, two adult sons, her parents-in-law and daughter-in-law. 

Nona is a veterinarian and owns a vet pharmacy. She offers medicines and vet service to a couple of nearby villages, including the treatment of domestic animals, vaccination of domestic animals and vet consultations. Villagers can purchase different types of vet medicines in her pharmacy. 

Nona’s family also owns two milk cows. Nona’s husband, Levan, handles the agricultural activities of the family. He makes cheese from the milk and sells it locally. 

With the requested loan, Nona plans to increase stock-in-trade in the pharmacy, as the season for vaccination starts in a month and demand on vaccines will increase in the villages. Nona plans to reinvest her profit in further expansion of the pharmacy and development of the dairy farm. In the long term, this reinvestment will positively impact the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase stock-in-trade (vaccines) for her vet pharmacy.

loans.name: Hiedeliza

texts.en:
Hiedeliza S. is from the village of Kabatangan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 50 years old, married, and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Hiedeliza owns & operates a business providing motorela or habal-habal transport services to local community members. Hiedeliza has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Hiedeliza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hiedeliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase tools needed to provide service. 

Hiedeliza is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP to purchase additional tools & supplies needed for the maintenance of her business. This loan will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchase tools & supplies needed for her transport business

loans.name: Fifamè Ginette

texts.fr: Ginette est née le 29 Juin 1980 au Bénin. Ginette est mariée à un certain Aimé et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple supporte ensemble les diverses charges de la maison. Il y a près de six ans que Ginette et sa famille se sont installées à PK10 dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji.
