Ginette mène comme activité la vente de plateaux d'œufs frais de façon ambulante ; ce qui l'aide à subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Ginette achète ses produits à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Ginette sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les deux premiers crédits ont tous été bien remboursés. Son ambition est de renforcer davantage son activité afin d'accroître son revenu.
texts.en: Ginette was born on 29 June 1980 in Benin. She is married to a man named Aimé and is the mother of two children, both of whom are in school. The couple takes care of the various household expenses together. Close to six years ago, Ginette and her family settled in the PK10 area of the town of Sèmè-Podji. Ginette runs a business selling cartons of fresh eggs in a door-to-door fashion; this helps her provide for herself and her children. She buys her goods in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. With the goal of strengthening her business and better satisfying her clientele, Ginette is seeking a third loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners). The two previous loans were both repaid properly. Her ambition is to further strengthen her business in order to raise her income.

loans.use: To buy cartons of fresh eggs

loans.name: Rejoice

texts.en: Rejoice A. is 38 years old.  She is currently in the business of selling fruits & vegetables. She is married to a teacher and they have four children, all of whom are in school.  Her future goal is to buy more goods.

loans.use: stock more fruits & vegetables to sell

loans.name: Nyoka

texts.en: A. is currently in the business of selling soft drinks. She is 39 years old, married, and has 5 children -- all of whom go to school. A. borrowed a loan to stock more soft drinks to sell.  In the future, she hopes to build a rental house with the extra profits from her business.

loans.use: stock more soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Ferly

texts.en:
Ferly S. is from the village of Pinamulaan, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 28 years old, married,  and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Ferly owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling beverages, snack foods, canned goods, shampoo, soap & biscuits in the local community. Ferly has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Ferly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & fund working capital.

Ferly is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP to purchase more beverages, canned goods & snack foods to sell. This loan will be her 6th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: buy beverages, canned goods and snack foods to resell

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa G. is married to a farmer and they have four children. She has been supplementing her husband’s income for the past 10 years by selling snails and medicinal drugs (as shown in the photograph). Adjoa does not have a store, so she carries her wares on her head and goes around her village, Mfuom, to make her sales.

Adjoa wishes to grow her business.  This loan will help her purchase more snails and more varieties of drugs to cater to the needs of her customers. She plans to save up the anticipated extra earnings for her family’s future.

loans.use: purchase more snails and medicine to sell

loans.name: Khodor

texts.en:
Khodor has been selling coffee by going past shops in his region and serving them his hot, well done coffee since 2000. He is a 43-year-old married man, the father of six children. Khodor lives with his family in Saida. Khodor lived through a miserable financiA. situation with his family, and he doesn't want his kids to face what he faced. That's why he wants to improve his business with his eighth loan from A. Majmoua. He will buy a car and widen his selling zone.

Khodor is a good borrower. His previous loans helped him a lot socially and financially. Most of his clients are neighbors and friends. He hopes to provide his family a healthy and secure life.

loans.use: to buy a car to improve his coffee business.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel is a hardworking gentleman who is 25 years old.  He owns a general store in which he sells water, biscuits, exercise books, soap and juices. He has owned this store for 3 years.  Samuel is requesting a loan to buy more items such as soap, drinking water, and books in order to make more profits.  With the profits he plans to buy goats to raise. His future plan is to save money and later on open up a wholesale store.

loans.use: buy more items to sell in his shop

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane D. is 32 years old.  She is currently in the business of selling clothes.  She is married to a teacher and they have five children, all of whom are in school.  Her future goal is to develop her business.

loans.use: stock more clothes to sell

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
For the past four years, Abena G. has been selling gari and kenkey in her village Mfuom, near Abura town in the Central Region.  Gari is a Ghanaian staple painstakingly made from cassava and can be eaten in a variety of ways. Kenkey is another staple made from fermented cassava and corn dough. 

Abena is married and has six children.  Her sale of gari and kenkey supplements her husband’s income as a farmer. She helps pay the cost of sending their children to school – mainly school uniforms and books, and also some of the utilities bills. 

In order to save up for higher education fees for her children, Abena needs to increase her earnings. To do so, she plans to expand her business with her loan from Kiva. With it she will purchase more cassava, corn, and other ingredients to prepare more food for sale. Part of the anticipated extra earnings will be put back into the business to grow it further and the rest will be saved for her family’s future.

loans.use: buy cassava, corn and other ingredients to prepare  food for sale

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita P. is from the village of Pinamulaan, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 60 years old, married, and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Anita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, beverages, shampoo, soap & detergents in the local community.  She has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Anita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & fund working capital for her business. 

Anita is requesting a new loan of 23000 PHP to purchase more canned goods, snack foods, beverages & detergents to sell. This loan will be her 7th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: buy canned goods, snack foods, beverages & detergents to sell

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud is a 42-year-old married man, living with his wife and four children in Saida. Mahmoud is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, in order to buy necessary wood for his business. This is Mahmoud's tenth loan with Al Majmoua, and all his previous loans were productive. 

Mahmoud is a hard-working man with a good reputation. He started his own business in 1987. He is working hard to expand his business in order to reach a size where he can retire and rest knowing that he has a small capital to rely on for the rest of his life, in addition to providing his children, Mohamad (20), Hussein (15), Fawziyah (16), and Aisha (15), with the best education and living standard.

Mahmoud hopes to expand his business so he can leave it to his kids when he dies.

loans.use: To buy wood necessary for manufacturing business.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther T. is married and has two children. She received schooling through junior high school. For the past five years, Esther has been selling smoked fish at Mfuom near Abura to supplement her husband’s income. Her husband is a farmer and shoe maker. Her earnings help pay for their children’s school fees and the household utilities bills. 

Esther's goal now is to increase her earnings so that she and her husband can save up money for their children's higher education.  With a loan from Kiva, she will purchase more fish to sell. She plans to save the additional earnings from the increased sales.

loans.use: buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Nkonya Nezikokolima Farmers Group

texts.en: M. Stephen is a 37-year-old gentleman who derives his livelihood from a fish sales business in Nkonya Landing in Mityana. This happily married father of 9 says he inherited this business from his father. Before that, he says farming was his major preoccupation. He still does farming and says he still harvests and sells most of the crops he grows. Weekly, he says this business generates for him 90,000 Ugandan shillings in profit. Stephen says he is asking for this loan to purchase fishing nets and manure for his farm gardens.

loans.use: purchase fish nets and fertilizer

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia V. is from the village of Kilikili, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 42 years old, married, and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Virginia owns & operates a business making general household furniture and selling them to local businesses and community members. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional raw materials to expand her product offerings. 

Virginia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase tools & other equipment to expand her business. This loan will be her 6th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: buy tools & equipment for her furniture business

loans.name: Afgan

texts.en:
Afgan O. is 25 years old. He lives in the village of Seidigodjalo, Marneuli district, with his mother. The only source of income for the family is agriculture. Afgan and his mother have a plot of the land where potatoes are grown. Also, they own greenhouses where cucumbers and tomatoes are grown. The products are sold locally. Total income for the family amounts to 1200 laris per month. 

Afgan requested a loan from Credo, as he plans to purchase fertilizers for his greenhouse. After the land is fertilized, the family will get more and better quality vegetables and sell them for a more convenient price. With the increase in income, Afgan and his mother will renovate their house in order to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers for vegetable growing.

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth S. is from the village of Christian Village, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 45 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Lilibeth owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap, and biscuits in the local community. Lilibeth has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Lilibeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilibeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods, and beverages. This loan will be Lilibeth's fifth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase canned goods, snack foods, and beverages

location.town: Christian Village, Wao, Lanao del Sur

loans.name: Davlatbi

texts.en: J. Davlatbi is an extremely hardworking and energetic woman. She is married and the loving mother of six children. Her husband works in Russia, and only she engages in animal husbandry. She has been in the business for 17 years. She purchases cattle and feeds them for a certain period; then sells cattle in the market. She would like to get a loan of 6,000 somoni to purchase cattle and expand her business. She hopes that the lenders will support her in the business. More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent viable business prospects. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: to buy cattle.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn S.'s main source of income comes from buying and selling rice per kilogram in her community. She is 35 years old, married and has five school-aged children. They are from the village of Kinura, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. Evelyn has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stock of rice. This will be her third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of rice.

loans.name: Geneviève

texts.fr: Geneviève est née en 1985 au Bénin et est mariée à un certain Ezéchiel. Geneviève est mère d'un enfant qui est scolarisé et à la charge du couple. Geneviève et sa famille vivent à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Geneviève mène comme activité la vente de friperies de différentes sortes ; ce qui l'aide à subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Geneviève achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et les revend de façon ambulante. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de satisfaire sa clientèle, Geneviève sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Geneviève a bien effectué le remboursement des deux premiers crédits obtenus. Son ambition est de renforcer davantage son activité afin d'accroître son revenu.
texts.en: Geneviève was born in 1985 in Benin and is married to a man named Ezéchiel. She is the mother of one child, who attends school and is in the couple's care. Geneviève and her family live in Ekpè in the town of Sèmè-Podji. Geneviève runs a business selling second-hand items of various kinds; this helps her provide for herself and her child. She buys her goods at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, and re-sells them door-to-door. With the goal of strengthening her business and satisfying her customers, Geneviève is seeking a third loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners). She repaid her two previous loans properly. Her ambition is to further strengthen her business in order to increase her income.

loans.use: To buy and sell second-hand goods (clothing, shoes, bags)

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina M. is 54 years old, widowed, and has three children who attend school.  She is a resident of Ascoville, Malaria, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is working hard to be able to send all her children to college, a dream for most Filipino parents like Angelina, who is a high school graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Angelina is a beautician and runs a small beauty salon in her home. Upon the request of customers, she provides home services doing manicures, pedicures, haircuts, hairdressing, and make-up. She also sells cosmetics offered by companies like Avon and Sara Lee. She has been engaged in this business for the 15 years and she now earns close to 11,000 PHP a month. She uses her earnings to provide for her family’s daily needs.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 24,000 PHP loan.  She is planning to use this loan to purchase supplies for her beauty parlor. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Angelina hopes that her business will continue to grow. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase beauty parlor supplies

loans.name: Majed

texts.en:
Majed is a 39-year-old married man, the father of three boys,  who lives in Saida with his precious family. Majed has worked as a furniture maker since 1985.  He specializes in furniture covers and sponge,  the second step in furniture making, after wood design and pasting.

Majed is requesting his fourth loan from A. Majmoua, to buy sponge, wood and textiles needed for his business. Majed is a borrower in good standing. His previous loans helped in opening a new business for his wife.  This supplemented their income and helped cover the family's expenses.  He hopes to expand his business more in the future and provide his children with the healthy activities that every child needs.

loans.use: To buy sponge, wood and textiles

loans.name: Shirly

texts.en:
Shirly V. is from the village of Paradise, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 51 years old, married, and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Shirly owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, detergents, instant noodles, shampoo, soap, and beverages in the local community. Shirly has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Shirly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Shirly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital. Shirly is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, detergents, and  beverages. This loan will be Shirly's fifth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase canned goods, detergents, and beverages

loans.name: Nyota Group

texts.fr: Kahambu M. M.  est entrepreneur, présidente du groupe d’affaire « Nyota »,  âgée de 30 ans, mariée, mère de 3 enfants. Son mari est un ingénieur dans une entreprise de communication « Air Tel ». La cliente Kahambu M. M. est vendeuse des pagnes. Elle  s’installe au marché central de Virunga. Il ya 7 ans qu’elle est exerce cette activité. Elle démarra son business avec de fonds propre reçu de sa grande sœur. Le capital initial fut 100$. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner avec des nouvelles marchandises (15 doubles des pagnes). En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise et scolariser ses enfants.  La cliente Kahambu M. M.  remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe d’affaire «  Nyota » est majoritairement féminins.
texts.en: Kahambu M. M. is a businesswoman and president of the business group "Nyota." She is 30 years old, married, and has 3 children. Her husband is an engineer for the telecommunications firm "Air Tel." Kahambu M. M. is a retailer of pagnes (a type of brightly-printed West African cloth). She is based at the central market in Virunga, and has run this business for 7 years. She launched her business with her own funds, which were given to her by her older sister. The initial capital was $100. This new loan is meant to help her supply herself with new merchandise (15 sets of pagnes). In addition, her ambition is to enlarge her business and educate her children. Kahambu M. M. is thankful to Hekima (one of Kiva's field partners) for its actions on behalf of the poor who are excluded from the traditional banking system. It is to be noted that the business group "Nyota" is composed primarily of women.

loans.use: To buy 15 sets of pagnes (a type of brightly-printed West African cloth)

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: To make a living, Esi A. sells both fish and palm kernel oil at her village, Mfuom, which is near Abura town in the Central Region. She has been selling both items for the past two years to supplement the household income. She is married to a trader. Her goal is to expand her businesses and with her loan, she will purchase larger quantities of both items to increase her sales. Her intention is to reinvest the earnings back into both businesses for further growth.

loans.use: To purchase fish and palm kernel oil

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann D. is from the village of Kalagutay, Ninoy Aquino, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 29 years old, married, and has three children. To make a living, Mary Ann owns and operates a motorela business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorela or habal-habal services to local community members. Mary Ann has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 14,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Mary Ann joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Ann has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase tools needed to provide service. Mary Ann is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tools and utilities needed for the maintenance of her motorela. This loan will be Mary Ann's seventh loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tools and utilities needed for the maintenance of a motorela

loans.name: Asliya

texts.en:
K. Asliya is divorced and has one child. She trades in the market of Sakhovat in the sector of Ganjina. She works very hard because the future of her child depends on her. She sells woman’s clothes and shoes. She has been in this business for eight years. She is requesting a loan of $1,000, which will use to purchase new fashionable clothes and to increase the assortment of goods for expansion of her business. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To buy new seasonal clothes

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa K. is a mother of four and is married to a tailor. She was educated up to senior high school. For the past 15 years, she has been selling fried fish (as shown in the photograph) at her village in Mfuom, near Abura town. Her income helps pay for her children’s school fees and some of the household expenses. 

In order to save up enough for her children’s tertiary education, she needs to grow her business and earnings.  A loan from Kiva will allow her to purchase larger quantities and varieties of fish for sale to cater the demands of her customers. She hopes that this will also help her attract new customers. Any extra income she earns will be set aside for her family’s future.

loans.use: to purchase larger quantities and varieties of fish for sale to cater to the demands of her customers.

loans.name: Mylene

texts.en:
This is Mylene E., 37, a resident of Tala, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Leo E., 37, who is also her business partner.  Mylene is a high school graduate and decided to manage a variety store while her children were small.

Mylene operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 Philippines pesos (PHP) worth of cooking oil or an egg. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at retail piece rates. Along with her variety store, she also sells viands (cooked dishes) to her neighbors. She earns a minimum of 400 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her businesses, she is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan.  She plans to use this loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages so as to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Mylene hopes that her business will continue to grow and be able to send her children all the way through college. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group’s weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.
 
*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional grocery items for her store.

loans.name: Marly

texts.en:
Marly M. is from the village of Ninoy Aquino in Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 33 years old. Marly is married and has four school-aged children. Marly runs a sari-sari shop (general store), selling canned goods, snack foods, biscuits, shampoo, soap and beverages in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2009 Marly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital. Marly is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, beverages and biscuits. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Marly from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, beverages and biscuits.

loans.name: Sala Sambila Plus Group

texts.en:
Julie is 31 and married with two daughters aged two and five years old. The oldest goes to school. 

Julie is the leader of the community bank named “Sala sambila Plus” which means "Work and pray" in English. The group is composed of five microentrepreneurs united in solidarity. The group was formed to receive loans from Kiva through the MFI HOPE DRC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Julie runs a restaurant. With her first loan from Hope, she has expanded her business by adding beverages that are in high demand where she works in eastern Kinshasa. 

Julie makes the equivalent of $150 per week in profit. She has been a faithful Hope client, having four times obtained and correctly repaid loans. Since taking out loans from Hope her business has prospered. 

Julie is planning to use the coming loan to increase the stock of her restaurant by purchasing fish, chickens and so on with the aim of increasing the profits. She is working very hard and would like to continue receiving Hope loans in order to achieve her dreams of modernising her restaurant by using electrical appliances, such as hot plates instead of charcoal. She also plans to open a soft drinks facility.

loans.use: to increase the inventory of her restaurant by purchasing fish, chickens and so on with the aim of increasing the profits.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua M. runs a drinks stall in Mfuom, near Abura town, in the Central Region of Ghana. She has been in this business for three years and her income contributes to her family’s household expenses and school fees. Akua is married to a mason and they have six children.

Akua M.'s goal is to expand her business and increase her earnings. Her loan from Kiva will enable her to purchase a higher volume and greater variety of drinks. She hopes this will help attract more customers and also cater to the needs of her existing customers. 

Ultimately, she wants to save up enough to put her children through university.

loans.use: to purchase a higher volume and greater variety of drinks.

loans.name: Ilia

texts.en:
Ilia A. is 30 years old. He is married and lives in the village of Boslebi in Kartli Region with his wife Lia and their three children.

The family has a grocery shop in the village. The shop functions profitably. In addition, Ilia and Lia have two milk cows. They use the milk cheese production. The cheese is sold locally. 

With the requested credit, two additional milk cows will be purchased. It will increase the income of the family as more cheese will be produced and sold. Ilia and Lia want to save and use their savings later for the education of the children and renovation of the house.

loans.use: to purchase milk cows

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua A. runs a chop bar, which is a food stall, in Mfuom, a village near the town of Abura. She sells fish and other food items, including fufu, a starchy Ghanaian staple made from cassava. In the photograph, she is shown preparing fufu. 

Married with four children, her income from the chop bar helps pay for her children's school fees and also the household expenses. 

Ekua plans to grow her business and requires a loan to purchase more ingredients. This will allow her to expand her menu, which she hopes will keep her existing customers coming back and also attract new ones. 

Any extra earnings will be reinvested into her business and the rest saved up for her children’s future.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients for her food stall.

loans.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita H. is from the village of Ninoy Aquino, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 42 years old. Florita is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Florita owns & operates a business planting & harvesting a variety of vegetables like string beans & pechay (chinese cabbage). Florita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Florita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Florita is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Florita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn N. is from the village of Ninoy Aquino, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 48 years old and married, with 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn makes and sells chicken and pork barbecue. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for more than 5 years and earns approximately 12000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional ingredients and as working capital. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients such as meat and spices. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients such as meat and spices

loans.name: Husniya

texts.en:
P. Husniya is married and has three children. Her husband works as a teacher in a local school. She sells children’s clothes in the market. Her current plan is to buy more children’s clothes so she can offer a wider variety of new garments. She needs the loan of $1600 for this reason. Let’s help her with this purchase and allow her to expand her business. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy new seasonal children’s clothes.

loans.name: Jemima

texts.en:
Jemima D. is married to a carpenter and they have eight children. To help support her family, Jemima has, for the past 20 years, been selling fish and red-red at Mfuom, a village near Abura. (Note: Red-red is a popular Ghanaian stew made of cow peas and served with fried plantains.)

To earn enough to put her children through higher education, Jemima needs to grow her business and earnings. She is requesting a loan so that she can purchase larger quantities of food to prepare and sell. Some of the additional earnings will be reinvested into her business and the rest will be set aside for her family’s future.

loans.use: to purchase larger quantities of food to prepare and sell.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
This is Marilyn D., 38, resident of Victoria Reyes, Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Adonis D., a contractual employee, and is the mother of four children, two of whom are in the elementary grades and the other two are not yet of school age. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send the rest of her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Marilyn, as she herself has been only through elementary school and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Marilyn is into the buying and selling of dried fish and smoked fish for quite some time now. She orders these items in large quantities from an individual who dries and smokes the fish.  She repacks the same into 5 PHP to 20 PHP packs for sale.  Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  Monthly, she earns an estimated net income of around $260.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 19,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy dried and smoked fish for her every day inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Marilyn dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for more dried and smoked fish for reselling.

loans.name: Muhammad

texts.en:
Muhammad is a young man from Jineen. He owns land in Yabad village in Jenin district. Muhammad is married and his wife helps him work their land. They grow seasonal fruits and vegetables and sell them to the vegetable stores in Jenin.

Muhammad who is photographed here took out a loan from FATEN to purchase a car and use it to distribute the crops over the stores he deals with. The car will help Muhammad reach more stores and have more clients which will increase their income.

loans.use: to purchase a car to transport his crops.

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua H. is the mother of eight. Married to a farmer, she helps support the family by selling waakye, which is rice cooked with beans, usually served with a fish stew. She has been in this business for five years and her earnings pay for their kids’ school fees and some household expenses.
 
She is keen to grow her business so that she can save up for her children’s higher education. Her loan from Kiva will allow her to purchase more rice, beans and other ingredients to increase the volume of food for sale. She intends to set aside the additional earnings for her family’s future.

loans.use: to purchase more rice, beans and other ingredients to increase the volume of food for sale.

loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
Anne C. is 33 years old and llives in Kakamega. She is married to Nelson. They have three children between the ages of eight and four.

She has a business of selling secondhand clothes. She has been in this business for the past nine years and has seen it grow through the years. She is applying for her second loan from KADET LTD and wants to use the money to buy more clothes to add to her stock.

Anne is very optimistic that her business will expand after she gets the loan. She hopes to open up a boutique in the future.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to add to her stock.

loans.name: Isabelita

texts.en:
Isabelita O. is from the village of Ninoy Aquino, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 50 years old. Isabelita is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, detergents, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $238 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Isabelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Isabelita is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products like canned goods, beverages and biscuits. This will be her 6th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated  to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more canned goods, beverages and biscuits to resell.

loans.name: Adjwoa

texts.en:
Adjwoa A. is a widow and supports her family through her palm oil business. In the photograph, Adjoa is pumping and filtering the oil. She has been doing this for ten years now. As the sole breadwinner of her family, Adjwoa wants the financial security of a higher income and increased savings. In order to do so, she has to expand her business.

Her Kiva loan will be used to purchase more palm fruit for oil extraction. She intends to save up the additional earnings for the security of her family’s future.

loans.use: to purchase more palm fruit for oil extraction.

loans.name: Fatheyya

texts.en:
Fatheyya is a mother of two daughters and four sons. She started up a business at her house; she started purchasing clothes and selling them to neighbors and relatives out of her home.

Fatheyya took out a loan from FATEN to purchase more clothes for the summer season and increase her profit. Fatheyya's son, who appears in the picture as she is a conservative woman, is a construction worker and helps her support the family.

loans.use: to purchase clothes to sell at home.

loans.name: Béatrice

texts.fr: Née en 1960 à Akpro-Missérété dans le département de l'Ouémé, Béatrice est marié à un revendeur du nom de Thimoléon. Béatrice est mère de quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés et qui vivent ensemble avec leurs parents. Il y a juste deux ans que la famille s'est installée à Djeffa dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges de la maison. Béatrice n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Il y a une dizaine d'année que Béatrice a commencé la vente de divers produits (savons, piles, bougies, conserves, condiments, des produits de soins, etc.). Cette activité lui génère des revenus l'aidant ainsi à assurer les besoins de sa famille. Béatrice s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est la deuxième fois que Béatrice sollicite auprès de ALIDé, son aide financière ; en vue de rehausser le niveau de son activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle. Le premier crédit obtenu a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
Born in 1960 in Akpro-Missérété, in Ouémé County, Béatrice is a woman married to a retailer by the name of Thimoléon. Béatrice is the mother of four children, who have all had schooling and who live together with their parents. Just two years ago, the family settled in Djeffa, in the commune of Sèmè-Podji. Together, the couple ensure that the various household expenses are covered. 

Béatrice did not attend school. Some ten years ago, she started selling a variety of goods (soaps, batteries, candles, canned foods, condiments, personal care products, etc.) This is a business that generates revenues for her which helps to meet the needs of her family. She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. 

This is the second time she has requested her financing from ALIDé with the aim of responding better to the requirements of her customers. The first loan obtained has been repaid

loans.use: to buy soaps, canned foods, candles, batteries, sweets, and condiments

loans.name: Ulmaskhon's Group

texts.en:
Ulmaskhon A. is the leader of this group. She is 51 and married to a teacher. Her husband works at a school and receives a monthly salary in the amount of 3,500 KGS. Together they brought up a son who is now 20 years old and works as a welder. Ulmaskhon herself works as a teacher, too. 

The family also cultivates agricultural products for making additional money. They have been cultivating cabbage and wheat for eleven years. Selling some part of the harvest, the family earns an additional $433 per month, approximately.  

Ulmaskhon applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase mineral fertilizers for farming.  In the future she wants to purchase furniture for their home to improve their living conditions.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizers.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi N. is a palm oil seller from the village of Mfuom, near Abura town. She has been in this business for two years, and in the picture you can see her extracting the palm oil from the fruit. She aspires to grow her business to improve her income. 

She plans to use her Kiva loan to purchase more palm fruit to increase her sales volume. She intends to save the additional income for her family’s future. 

Educated up to junior high school, Esi is married to a farmer and they have six children. Her income from palm oil helps pay for their children’s school fees and their utility bills.

loans.use: to purchase more palm fruit to increase her sales volume.

loans.name: Ala

texts.en:
Ala is a young woman from Jenin. Her husband, who appears in the picture here as she is a conservative woman, is working in transportation. He rented a cargo car and works transporting goods, crops, and all kinds of items to stores around the city and neighboring villages.

Ala wanted to help her husband in purchasing a car so that he can stop paying a chunk of his income to the rental agency. Ala took out a loan from FATEN for this purpose to add it to the amount her husband has been able to save.

loans.use: to purchase a cargo car for her husband to work in transporting goods.

loans.name: Rolinda

texts.en:
Rolinda T. is from the village of Ninoy Aquino, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 41 years old. Rolinda is married and has nine school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Her husband provides motorela or habal-habal services. Rolinda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $239 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rolinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Rolinda is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, beverages and biscuits. This will be her 7th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, beverages and biscuits to resell.

loans.name: Nyame

texts.en:
Nyame I. has 10 children to support. She is married to a farmer and supplements his income by selling palm oil in the Mfuom Village, which is near Abura town. She has been in this business for more than eight years. 

Nyame intends to grow her business and improve her income. Her Kiva loan will help her purchase more palm fruit for oil extraction and increase her sales. She plans to apply any additional savings to her children’s tertiary education.

Nyame is pictured standing close to the boiling palm fruit.

loans.use: to purchase more palm fruit for oil extraction and increase her sales.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
This is Elizabeth L., 46, a resident of C. Jose Street, Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Ramon L., an employee, and is the mother of three children, two of whom are already working, while the other one is still in school. By the grace of God, Elizabeth has managed to support her older child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send the rest of her children all the way through college, which is a dream for most Filipino parents like Helen, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Elizabeth has managed her own beauty salon for quite some time now. She is an all-around beautician and runs a small beauty salon in the comfort of her home. Upon the request of customers, she also provides home service, doing manicures, pedicures, haircuts, hairdressing and make-up. She also sells cosmetics offered by direct-selling companies like Avon and Sara Lee. Monthly, Elizabeth earns an estimated net income of around 12,000 PHP.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 48,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more supplies and new equipment needed for her salon operation. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Elizabeth hopes that her business will continue to grow and she will be able to send her youngest child to college.  She prays for good health and to be able to enjoy a peaceful life with her family. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and new equipment for salon

loans.name: Mouhamad Jamal

texts.en:
Mouhamad JamA. is a 55-year-old married man, living with his wife in Saida. Mouhamad JamA. has worked in furniture-making for 35 years. He's well known in the region and most of his clients enjoy dealing with him.

Mouhamad JamA. has been an A. Majmoua borrower for 12 years, and this is his 14th loan. All his previous loans were invested in improving his business more and more which affects his family's sociA. and financiA. situation positively.

Mouhamad JamA. is requesting a loan from A. Majmoua in order to buy necessary wood for his business. He works hard  at pleasing his customers and family. He hopes to improve his business more and expand his workplace.

loans.use: To buy necessary wood for his business.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia A. is from the village of Kimagting, Ninoy Aquino, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 60 years old, married and has one adult child. To make a living, Virginia owns and operates a business providing videoke, karaoke and computer games services for local community members. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2009, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide her service. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the service. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Virginia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of her service

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a wide variety of bowls to add to her business

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa F. is both a hairdresser and a food seller in Mfuom, a village near Abura town. Educated up to junior high school, she has been in these businesses for three years. 

To save up for the future, she wants to expand her businesses. Her Kiva loan will enable her to purchase more ingredients to increase her food production for sale. She will also be able to buy more hairpieces (extensions) and products for her hairdressing business. 

She plans to reinvest her additional earnings back into her business for further growth.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients to increase her food production for sale.

loans.name: Diloramhon's Group

texts.en: Diloramhon A. is the treasurer of this group. She is 28 and married. Her husband is a constructor and when he has free time, he works as a taxi driver. Together they are bringing up three daughters and a son. The two older daughters are at school and the other children are not yet as they are preschool age (under seven). In order to earn money, Diloramhon sells convenience goods. She started this activity three years ago by selling seeds and chewing gum. Now, as a result of her successful business, she has expanded her activity and rented a place for trade. She earns 3,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase more convenience goods in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future, she wants to start repairing her house and build a summer kitchen. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase convenience goods

loans.name: Rami

texts.en:
Rami is a young and ambitious man. With his friend, he started up a small computer company, selling all sorts of electronics and devices that are attached to computers such as mouse, hard drives, printers, etc.

Rami, who is photographed in the picture here, took out a loan from FATEN to purchase more of the above-mentioned items and increase sales, Rami and his friend wish to have a big business in the future and lead the computer electronics industry.

loans.use: to improve their company's work by purchasing computer devices and electronics.

loans.name: Kimatoy

texts.en:
Kimatoy S. is married and she has four children. 

Kimatoy works hard to provide for her family. She started her business with the selling of national foods. Today she runs the business of selling children’s clothes and shoes. She has been in this business for 11 years. Today her working capital is $5,000 USD. 

She hopes to receive a loan for purchasing new seasonal children’s clothes and for this reason she has requested $2,300 USD. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes having been a key post along the Silk Road and having witnessed the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to epic mountain passes, a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC, and communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty.

IMON's History:
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy children’s clothes.

loans.name: Delma

texts.en:
Delma C. is from the village of Ninoy Aquino, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 50 years old. Delma is married and has three adult children. 

To make a living, Delma owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, detergents, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Delma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Delma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Delma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Delma is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods and detergents. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Delma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods and detergents.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
This is Susana S., 44, a resident of C. Jose St., Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Cerilo S., a janitor, and is the mother of two children who are studying in college while the other one is already working. 

At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her youngest child all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Susana, as she herself is a high school graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Susana operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP’s-worth of cooking oil or an egg. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at retail piece rates. She earns a minimum of 200 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her variety store, she is requesting a 25,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages so as to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Susana hopes that her business will become bigger and she will be able to build a bigger commercial place. She also prays for having their own house and lot for her family. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group’s weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.
 
*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional grocery items and beverages for her store.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a young man from Qalqilia. Ahmad runs a small mobile phone accessories store and repair workshop. Ahmad took out a loan from FATEN to purchase a mobile phone repair kit that would help him fix more phones with different problems as well as buying more mobile accessories to increase sales.

Ahmad who appears in the picture here helps his father support the family. His father runs a small grocery store in Qalqilia.

loans.use: to purchase  a mobile phone repair kit and parts.

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester S. 30 years old. She is married to a farmer and they have three children. All of the children are in school. 

Currently, she is in a business of selling fish and her goal is to buy more fish to sell.

loans.use: to stock more fish to sell.

loans.name: Sheila

texts.en:
Sheila M. is from the village of Ninoy Aquino, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 26 years old. Sheila is married and has two infant children. 

To make a living, Sheila owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Sheila has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Sheila joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sheila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional stock and for working capital. 

Sheila is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods and beverages. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Sheila from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods and beverages.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more fruits and  vegetables from rural farmers for resale.

loans.name: Randa

texts.en:
Randa is the wife of Muhammad who appears in the picture here as she is a conservative woman and a mother of five daughters and one son. Randa's husband is a taxi driver.

Randa's husband wants to fix the car he drives in order to have a better income as the car would be working for longer hours with better performance.

loans.use: to repair the taxi Randa's husband drives.

loans.name: Asenia

texts.en:
Asenia C. is from the village of Kalagutay, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 60 years old. Asenia is married and has three adult children. 

To make a living, Asenia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling  canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Asenia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Asenia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Asenia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Asenia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, beverages and breads. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Asenia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, beverages and breads.

loans.name: Mayrambi

texts.en:
Mayrambi O. is a hardworking woman who has three children. Her husband is a driver. 

She sells clothes and shoes. Her family helps her in this business. Her husband has his own car and he imports the goods from the wholesale market for his wife’s business. 

She would like to get a loan of 8,000 TJS for the purchasing of new seasonal clothes and the expansion of her business.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes having been a key post along the Silk Road and having witnessed the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy seasonal spring clothes and shoes.

loans.name: Rotchelyn

texts.en:
Rotchelyn S. is from the village of Ninoy Aquino, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 28 years old. Rotchelyn is married and has one school-aged child. 

To make a living, Rotchelyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, breads, snack foods, shampoo, soap and detergents. Rotchelyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rotchelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Rotchelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 21,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital.
