Rotchelyn is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, beverages and snack foods. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Rotchelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, beverages and snack foods.

loans.name: Dioubo Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité de DIOUBO est créé le 27 août 2009. Il est composé de 12 femmes qui toutes issues du même quartier. Leur activité principale est le petit. Le fait partie du Banc Villageois de MAMADOU LAMINE G.. 

Madame NDACK MAI F. (debout à l'extrême droite de la photo emmitouflée d'une écharpe marron) est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 40 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants. Elle a en charge son neveu. 

Elle fait un petit commerce de poissons au marché central de la ville. Et parallèlement elle vend des tissus. Elle a une bonne expériences dans ces domaines d'activité pour les avoir menées depuis plus de trois ans. 

Avec son nouveau crédit elle va augmenter son niveau d'approvisionnement en poissons et tissus pour mieux fidéliser sa clientèle et générer des revenus financiers.

Son objectif est de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge de la santé des membres de la famille et de la scolarités des enfants.
texts.en:
The solidarity group DIOUBO was created on August 27, 2009. It is composed of twelve women who are all from the same neighborhood. Their principal business involves small-scale commerce. The group is part of the Banc Villageois of MAMADOU LAMINE G.. 

Ms. NDACK MAI F. (standing at the far right in the photo and snug in a brown scarf) is the group’s leader. She is 40 years old, married, and the mother of four children. And she has her nephew in her care. She has a small business involving fish at the city's central market. And concurrently, she sells fabrics. She has good experience in these business domains for having run them for over three years.  

With her new loan, she is going to increase her supplies of fish and fabrics, so as to retain her customers and to generate revenues. Her goal is to support her husband in meeting the health care needs of the family and the schooling costs of the children.

loans.use: to buy fish to be resold at the market

loans.name: Bakari

texts.en:
Bakari is a single woman who owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and clothing. For the past six years, she has operated a food stall business cooking chapati, beans, peas and rice for sale at home to sell to her neighbors and passers-by. 

She faces a major challenge of high competition from other food stall operators and the seasonality in her business. Bakari dreams of establishing a restaurant business in the future. With the Kshs 40,000 she is requesting, she wants to purchase bundles of maize flour, wheat flour, sugar and cooking fat oil. She decided to work with Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of maize flour, wheat flour, sugar and cooking fat oil.

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa B. is divorced and the sole breadwinner for her three children. To support her family, she has been selling kenkey (a Ghanaian staple made from fermented maize dough) for the past four years in Mfuom, a village near Abura. 

She needs to increase her earnings for her family’s financial security and wants to expand her business. Yaa will use her loan from Kiva to purchase more maize and other ingredients to grow her food business. Extra earnings will be reinvested into her business and also set aside for her children’s university educations.

loans.use: to purchase more maize and other ingredients to grow her food business

loans.name: Cheneta

texts.en:
This is Cheneta G., 50, a resident of Domingo Street, Malibay, Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Eduardo G., a trash collector, and is the mother of five children.  Three of the children are already married, one is working while the other one is not yet of school age.  Cheneta is an elementary school graduate, yet decided to manage a micro-enterprise to help her husband earn a living.

Cheneta has operated a hardware store for almost two years now. She also has been managing and running their junk shop for 28 years and has been selling used clothing for 12 years. Having her husband as business partner, Cheneta earns an estimated net income of around 12,000 PHP monthly.

To help her continue the operation of her businesses, she is requesting a 24,000 PHP loan.  She plans to use this loan to buy more items for her hardware store and part of this loan will be used as revolving capital for her junk shop. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
 
Cheneta dreams of being able to give all of her children a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work in her business. She also prays for having her own commercial space for her junk shop. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group’s weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives
 
*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional hardware items for her store

loans.name: Sojidamo

texts.en:
N. Sojidamo is a hard-working woman who is married and has four children. Her husband and son help her in her grocery sales business. She lives near the market of Sakhovat. She purchases goods from wholesalers and sells them at a retail price. Before, she did not have the opportunity for a wide range of goods, but now she has a large assortment of goods. Sojidamo would like to get a loan of 5,000 Somoni to purchase a new selection of goods due to market demand and to increase the assortment of goods in her business. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy grocery goods

loans.name: Vagif

texts.en:
Vagif N. lives in the village of Mushevani, Bolnisi District. He is 45 years old, married and lives with his wife, Lachin, and two sons (24 and 22 years old). Vagif runs a grocery store in his village. He buys groceries in Marneuli (a nearby town) and sells them in his store. Along with the grocery store the N.’s family is engaged in agricultural activities: They grow potatoes, haricot beans, and maize. The grains and vegetables are sold locally. 

Vagif requested a loan to increase his stock-in-trade in the store. This will increase the income of the family and will help them to purchase some furniture for their house.

loans.use: to purchase stock-in-trade for his grocery store.

loans.name: Moustafa

texts.en:
Moustafa is a 36-year-old married man, living with his wife and three children in Saida. Moustafa has worked as car electrician for 23 years. He's an expert in his field since he started this business in his early childhood. Moustafa was very close to his big brother, he was his role model and seeks to be like him, that's why he started working with him and that's how he learned his first business knowledge. 

Moustafa is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the 11th time, in order to buy tools necessary to improve his business, in addition to buying new bedrooms for his children. 

Moustafa is a borrower in good standing, a man with a good reputation who deserves his business. 

He hopes to provide his family a good life filled with health, happiness and good education. He hopes to buy some land where he can build a house for each  of his kids.

loans.use: to buy tools necessary for his business

loans.name: Mena

texts.en:
Mena A. is married and has four children. Her husband is a farmer. To help him support the family, Mena sells banku (a local staple made from maize dough, usually served with stew or soup) at her village, which is near the town of Abura. Her income helps pay for their children’s school fees and some household expenses. 

Mena wants to grow her business so that she can save up enough to support her children through university. In order to do so, she needs a loan from Kiva to buy larger quantities of ingredients so that she can prepare more food for sale. She intends to reinvest some of the extra earnings back into her business for further growth and save up the rest for her children’s futures.

loans.use: to buy larger quantities of ingredients so that she can prepare more food for sale

loans.name: Zorik

texts.en:
A 50-year-old resident of Ddmashen village, Sevan area, Zorik M. is married and has a son and a daughter, the latter a student. Zorik, his wife and his son are engaged in farming, raising cows, pigs and chickens, the income from which pays for his daughter’s education and supports his family. He now
needs a 300.000 AMD loan to repair his cattle shed’s roof.

loans.use: to repair his cattle shed’s roof.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi E., married to a farmer and the mother of seven children, was educated through senior high school. For the past eight years, she has been making and selling soap in her village to help her husband with the household expenses and school fees. In the photograph, Esi is shown collecting palm oil, a key ingredient in soap-making.

Esi is determined to grow her business and so needs a loan from Kiva to help her increase her soap-making production. With the resulting increased sales volume and earnings, she will reinvest money into her business, but her ultimate priority is to save enough to put her children through university.

loans.use: to increase her soap-making production.

loans.name: Metalida

texts.en: Metalida J. is 30 years old. She's currently in business selling fruits and vegetables. Married to a farmer, she has six children. All of them are in school. Her future goal is to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to stock more fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Maame E. is married to a farmer and they have two children. She has completed her junior high school education.

To make a living, Maame runs a small provisions and food items stall in Mfuom where she sells sponges and tins of fish and tomatoes and onions. She has been running this business for three years and her income helps pay her children’s school fees. 

She wants to grow her business: increase sales amongst her existing customers and also attract new ones. A loan would enable her to buy more food items for resale. She plans to re-invest any extra earnings she has back into her business for long-term growth.

loans.use: to  buy more food items for resale.

loans.name: Charlita

texts.en:
Charlita L. is 47 years old, married to Paul, and blessed with three adult children. One of them is already working and the other two are still studying. At this time, Charlita is working hard to be able to send her younger children to college, a dream for most Filipino parents like Charlita as she herself is a college graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Charlita is an all-around beautician and runs a small beauty salon in the comfort of her home. Upon the request of customers, she also provides home service doing manicure, pedicure, haircuts, hairdressing and make-up. She also sells cosmetics offered by direct selling companies like Avon and Sara Lee. She has been enjoying this kind of work for the last fifteen years and she now earns close to 11,000 PHP a month. She uses her earnings to answer to her family’s daily needs.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 19,000 PHP loan. She is planning to use this loan to purchase supplies for her beauty parlor. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Charlita hopes that her business will continue to grow and that she will be able to send all her children all the way through college. She is also desirous of having another branch of her beauty salon to manage. Charlita prays for good health and a happy life for her entire family. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for supplies needed for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine W. is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. They live at a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent bills, school fees and clothing. 

She has had a retail shop business for the past 12 years, selling household consumable items like wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar. She faces a major challenge of competition from other retail shop operators in her area of operation. 

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With the KES 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en:
Jacob S. A. is 29 years old, married to Evalyne, and they are blessed with two children who are still young. He has been in the transport industry for the past year and earns a profit margin of KES.15,500 monthly.

Jacob, who was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer, is requesting his first loan with which he plans to buy another motorbike for the business. He will use the anticipated extra profits to repay the loan and save money to buy more motorbikes. A very hardworking and focussed businessman, Jacob desires to grow his business and have a fleet of motorcycles operating on different routes in Kitengela and along the Athi River.

loans.use: to buy another motorbike.

loans.name: Rehab

texts.en:
Rehab is a 43-year-old married woman who has 10 children, four of them already working. Rehab has a full time job at a health center, but that wasn’t enough to help in supporting her family, so they decided to build a cattle farm around their house.

Rehab has been working in the farm for eight years now and own 12 cows, but since the farm's capacity is 20 cows, she applied for this loan to buy more cows.

Note: Rehab and her husband appear in the picture.

loans.use: To buy more cows for her cattle farm.

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa K. is a single mother of six children. As the sole provider for her family, she makes a living by selling palm oil. First, she purchases the palm fruit (shown in the photograph) and through a process of boiling and filtering, extracts the oil from the fruit.

To increase her income, she is very keen to expand her business. She will use her Kiva loan to purchase more palm fruit so that she can extract more oil for sale. 

The education of her children is of utmost importance to her and her business expansion will help her save up for their future.

loans.use: to purchase more palm fruit so that she can extract more oil for sale

loans.name: Adolat

texts.en:
S. Adolat is married and has one child. She lives in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. Her son (who is in this photo) helps her in this business. She has two working places in the market of Shohmansur and that’s why she needs a wider assortment of more goods. Two years ago, during a fire in the market, her goods were burned and she left without capital. With the help of IMON International, she started her business again. Now she plans to purchase a new assortment of goods and for this she has requested a loan of 3,000 USD. 
   
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy women’s underwear and children’s clothes for sale

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice M. is 30 years old. She is married to a farmer, and they have five children, who are all in school.

She's currently in the business of selling fish and has taken out a loan to stock more fish to sell. Her future goal is to stock more goods to sell.

loans.use: to stock more fish

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay back his brothers for the money he borrowed.

loans.name: Kugumikiriza Group

texts.en: Thirty-year-old Ben T. has been operating his general merchandise retail shop for the past decade in Mailo Mbili-Jinja. Ben, the father of two, says this worthwhile business undertaking has enabled him to make strides in many aspects of his life. Not everything has come easily, but he has banked on his diligence and tenacity to stabilize his business, which generates a weekly profit of shillings 100,000. Ben will use this loan to purchase more general merchandise stock to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more general retail stock to resell.

loans.name: Joice

texts.en: Joice T., 36 years old, currently sells fruits and vegetables. Married to a policeman and the mother of four children, all in school, Joice's goal is to buy more goods.

loans.use: to stock more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Muhammad

texts.en:
Muhammad is a young man from Tulkarem. He works in a car repair shop and when he needs extra money he works in workshops on the other side of the green line. Muhammad took out a loan from FATEN to pay for house repair expenses, especially ceiling damage after the winter.

Muhammad who appears in the picture here is married and has no children.

loans.use: to pay for house improvement--painting, fixing ceiling, fixing windows.

loans.name: Nassif

texts.en: Nassif is a 37-year-old married man and father of three children, living and working with his family in Saida. Nassif has sold DVDs & CDs since 2005. He sells movie and music DVDs and CDs. Nassif is a hard worker. He seeks perfection for his family, that's why he's requesting a loan from A. Majmoua to buy a CD and DVD writer, which will increase his net profit from the increased income he'll gain. This is his sixth loan with A. Majmoua, and all of the previous loans had a great impact on his life and he paid them all on time. He hopes to open his own shop in the future instead of selling his products on the streets.

loans.use: to buy a CD & DVD writer

loans.name: Selina

texts.en:
Selina is a married woman with three school-going children. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing, electricity bills and school fees.

For over ten years, she has operated a clothing sales business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. Selina faces a major challenge of competition from other clothes sellers in the market. She dreams of expanding her business in the future. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she is requesting she wants to pay school fees for her child. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her child.

loans.name: Lona

texts.en: Lona , 50 years old, is currently in business of selling food. The loan will pay to stock more food. Married to a businessman, she has four children who all go to school. Her future goal is to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to stock more food.

loans.name: Nyakabungo Tukwatanise Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
Charles T., the leader of Nyakabungo Tukwatanise group in Ibanda, is a 38-year-old married father of four children, three of whom are in school. In the business of selling produce such as beans, millet, ground nuts and maize, he operates his enterprise from Nyakabungo, selling mostly to other bigger traders from neighboring districts and town dwellers. Charles has been in the business for over five years after having worked for someone else and is able to make 200,000/= as weekly profits. He also grows cotton and coffee.

A very hard-working and determined man, Charles needs a loan to buy more produce for resale. His dream is to grow his business.

loans.use: to buy more produce for resale.

loans.name: Hiba

texts.en:
Hiba is a young woman from Qalqilia. She is married and has no children. Hiba's husband runs a computer accessories store in the city. He sells accessories such as printers, mouse pads, hard disks, memory sticks, etc. Hiba took out a loan from FATEN as her husband wants to purchase a large number of these items to increase his sales and profit. 

Hiba's husband appears in the picture here, as she is a conservative woman.

loans.use: to purchase computer accessories to sell in a computer store.

loans.name: Saodat

texts.en:
Saodat H. is married and has three children. She lives in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. She trades in a small market near the station. She sells fruit, vegetables and salads. Her husband and daughter help her in this business she has had for 15 years. Her husband has his own car and helps her with transporting goods. Besides this business,  Saodat is engaged in sewing  national dresses. Her daughter takes orders at home. Saodat plans to use part of the loan to purchase fruit and to use the remainder to purchase fabric, because in the spring there is a demand for national dresses. For this reason Saodat has requested a loan of 1500 USD. 
   
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy fruit and fabric

loans.name: Saidia

texts.en: Saidia C. 32 years old. She's currently in the business of selling food. She's married to working man and has two children who are in school. Her future goal is to build a house.

loans.use: to stock more food to sell.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice B., 35, is currently in the business of selling alcohol and will use this loan to stock more alcohol. Married to a working man and the mother of seven children, only two of whom go to school, Alice hopes to open a shop in the future.

loans.use: to stock more alcohol to sell.

loans.name: Bikuweraki Women's Group

texts.en: Magumba N. is a 32 year old poultry sales business woman based in Jinja. She also sells eggs and young chicks. She says to start this business, she relied on savings from her food sales enterprise. The food business is still in existence and she says with earnings from it she has been able to increase her profit base. This business has now lasted two years and N. says it has called for a lot of determination and courage. Weekly, N. who is a mother to 4, says this business generates her shillings 100,000. She says with this loan she is going to buy layer chicken and chicken mash.

loans.use: The purchase of layer chicken and chicken mash.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret N. lives in the Kawempe neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has six children, all of whom are in school. Margaret has a business of selling soft drinks.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Eva sells her products in a shop, by means of retail.  Margaret has requested a loan of 800000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more more crates of soda, passion fruit, and sugar.  She also generates additional income through rental rooms.

The main business challenge(s) for Margaret include seasonality, transportation and thieves.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to build more rental rooms and also to own a soda depot.  Margaret lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family

loans.use: to buy more crates of soda, passion fruits, and sugar to sell.

loans.name: Diam Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Diam est créé le 27 août 2009 et fait partie du Banc Villageois Mamadou Lamine Guéye. Il est composé de 14 femmes qui habitent le même quartier.Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame Ndéye Coumba F. est la responsable du groupe. Elle est à l'extrême droite de la photo et tendant la main.Elle est âgée de 30 ans, mariée avec deux enfants et a son neveu en charge.

Elle mène une activité de petit commerce de produits cosmétiques et fait de la couture aussi. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ces domaines.

Son nouveau prêt lui permettra d'augmenter ses produits pour réaliser des bénéfices.

Elle va soutenir son mari pour la prise en charge des dépenses des membres de sa famille et renforcer son épargne.
texts.en:
The solidarity group, Diam, was created on 27th August 2009 and is part of the Banc Villageois in Mamadou Lamine Guéye. It is made up of 14 women who live in the same neighborhood. Their principal activity is trading on a small scale.

Mrs. Ndéye Coumba F. is in charge of the group. She is on the far right of the photo and holding out her hand. She is 30 years old and married with two children and her nephew in her care.

She has a small trading activity selling cosmetics and also does sewing. She has experience in both these fields. Her new loan will allow her to increase her products in order to make a profit. She will help her husband in covering the family expenses and strengthen her savings.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics with a view to selling them

loans.name: Eva

texts.en: Eva N. lives in the kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 4 children, all of whom are in school.  Eva has a business in a restaurant.  She has been in this business for less than one year, and she works seven days out of every week. Eva sells her products in a shop, by means of wholesale/retail.  Eva has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas, chicken beef, Irish and sweet potatoes, cassava, and maize.  She also generates additional income through rental rooms and charcoal.  The main business challenge(s) for Eva  include seasonality, transportation and defaulters.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to build more rental rooms and also to own a fully stocked hotel.  Eva lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family and rent for business premise.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas, chicken, beef, Irish and sweet potatoes, cassava, and maize flour.

loans.name: Cicilia

texts.en: Cicilia K. is 38 years old.  She is currently in the business of selling alcohol.  She is a widow with two children both in school.  Her future goal is to open a shop.

loans.use: Stock more alcohol for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase timber and a cutting machine.

loans.name: Albert

texts.en:
Albert S. is 57 years old. He is married and lives in the village of Bulbulistsikhe, Khashuri district. Agriculture is the only source of income for Albert and Marina (his wife). They have two milk cows and one bull. Milk is used to make cheese, which is sold on the local market. Also the family owns one hectare of land where haricot, maize, cucumbers, tomatoes and onions are grown. The vegetables are sold locally. Along with the above-mentioned activities, Albert has a truck that he uses for transporting agricultural products and materials. This truck is an additional source of income for the family. 

With the requested loan, Albert plans to purchase a mini (hand) tractor. In the future, Albert won’t hire a tractor for tilling his plot. It will significantly reduce his expenses for tilling. Also, Albert will rent his tractor to neighbor farmers and get extra income. 

Albert and Marina plan to reinvest their profit in dairy farm development. Also they want to renovate their house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase a mini tractor

loans.name: Famous Group

texts.en:
Mohamed B. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Born 40 years ago in Matotoka village, Mohamed is married and has 5 children.  For 10 years now, Mohamed has been selling medicines. He is going to use his share of the loan (SLL 1,000,000) to expand his business and buy medicines for resell.  

This is the first loan that Mohamed and his group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions.

loans.use: To buy medicines for resell.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 33-year-old married man and the father of three young children. He is from Lebanon. He has been working as a car dealer for the past five years. His business consists of buying used cars, making the needed maintenance on them and reselling them to make good profits. He offers his customers all types of cars and always responds to the market's demands. In parallel, this man has worked in a car rental shop since 2006.  He is thankful for his income; it helps satisfy his family needs. He has obtained two Kiva loans and has a very good repayment history. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase a new car in order to expand his business. In the future, he is planning to open his own car showroom.

loans.use: to purchase a new car

loans.name: Mtawali

texts.en:
Mtawali is a single man who lives in a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are rent bills, food and clothing. 

For the past five years, he has operated a green grocery business.  He sells from home to his neighbours and passersby. Mtawali faces a major challenge of competition from other green grocers operators in his area of operation. He dreams of expanding his business in the future.

With the Kshs 35,000 he wants to purchase one sack of green vegetables, potatoes and tomatoes. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase one sack of green vegetables, potatoes, and tomatoes.

loans.name: Honorine

texts.fr: Honorine est née en 1969 et est mariée à un transitaire nommé Eugène. Honorine a cinq enfants, tous scolarisés et qui sont tous à sa charge. Il y a près de cinq ans que Honorine et sa famille se sont installées à PK11, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Honorine vient en aide à son mari en assurant avec lui les diverses charges de la maison. Pour y arriver, Noudégodo Honorine mène comme activité la vente de liqueurs, de fruits et divers autres produits (conserves, lait, mayonnaise, beurre, huile d'arachide, amuses gueule, etc.), ce qui l'aide à subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Noudégodo Honorine achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et aussi à Lomé au Togo, et les revend à Sèmè-Podji. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de satisfaire sa clientèle, Honorine sollicite pour la première fois un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Son ambition est de renforcer davantage son activité afin d'accroître son revenu.
texts.en:
Honorine was born in 1969 and is married to a freight agent named Eugène. She has to support her five children, who all attend school. Honorine and her family have been living for almost five years in PK11 in Sèmè-Podji. She helps her husband in taking care of the various expenses of the family. To manage it, Honorine sells liquors, fruits, and various other products (canned food, milk, mayonnaise, butter, peanut oil, snacks, etc.) which helps her provide for herself and her children.

Honorine gets her supplies in Dantokpa, an international marketplace in Benin, as well as in Lomé, Togo. She resells in Sèmè-Podji. With the goal of bolstering her business and meet customer demand, she's seeking her first loan from Kiva's partner, ALIDé. She ambitions to bolster her business in order to increase her income.

loans.use: to buy liquors, apples, oil, and other various items

loans.name: Wazma

texts.en:
Wazma is a 49-year-old married woman who has six children to raise. She lives in an almost isolated area far from some services.
Wazma recently started a small business selling different kinds of snacks and food supplies at her house, benefiting from the fact that there is no close supermarket in the area where she lives. She noticed that her neighbors started to come and buy and ask for other products.
In order to be able to cover all the area needs, Wazma is applying for a loan to add more variation in her products based on her clients’ requests, so she can later on expand her business and open her own mini-market in the area.

loans.use: To add more variation in the food products that she sells at her house.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose K. is 22 years old and is currently in a business of selling alcohol.  She is married to a working man and they have three children, but only one goes to school.  Her future goal is buy more goods.

loans.use: Stock more alcohol to sell.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah is a 45 year old business-lady who sells construction materials.  She is able to raise her four children on her own with the income from her business.  She also earns extra income from her rental units.  Besides all of this, she does farming.  Through Faulu Kenya, she has learned how to keep business records hence proper management of her business.  She has requested for 80,000 Kes to buy sand, ballast and quarry dust.

loans.use: To buy sand, ballast, and quarry dust.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine is 38 years, she has five children who are between the ages 2-20 years.  All of her children are in school except the two young ones. Christine sells bananas, sorghum and other drinks.  She has been selling these products for six years and this business has enabled her to pay the children’s school fees and feed her family.  Christine is requesting a loan to buy more sorghum and green bananas in order to make more profits.

loans.use: To buy sorghum and green bananas for sale.

loans.name: Sebena

texts.en: Sebena Y. is 40 years old.  She is currently in the business of selling vegetables.  She will use the loan to stock more vegetables.  She is a widow with seven children who are all in school.  Her future goal is to pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: Stock more fruits and  vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a married woman with two children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are rent bills and school fees. 

For the past two years, she has operated a natural fruit juice making business that she sells from home to her neighbours and local residents. Margaret faces a major challenge of seasonality in her area of operation. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000 sheshe wants to repair her freezer and purchase a variety of flavors for making juice. Margaret decided to work with Yehu Microfinance because of efficiency of their loan products.

loans.use: To repair her freezer and purchase a variety of flavors for making juice.

loans.name: Diamaguene Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Diamaguéne fait partie du Banc Villageois Mamadou Lamine Guéye. Il est créé le 27 août 2009 et est composé de 11 femmes qui sont issues du même quartier. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame Aïssatou Bâ est la responsable du groupe, elle est à droite sur la photo et à croisé ses mains.         Elle est mariée avec un enfant en charge.

Elle mène une activité de petit commerce de tissus thioub, wax, khartoum et parallèlement des poissons fumés.

Elle souhaite avec son nouveau prêt agrandir son activité afin d'avoir beaucoup de revenus.

Les bénéfices obtenus lui ont permis de rénover sa maison.
texts.en:
Solidarity group Diamaguéne is part of the Banc Villageois Mamadou Lamine Guéye. It was established on August 27, 2009, and is composed of 11 women who come from the same neighborhood. Their main business is retail.

Madame Aïssatou Bâ is the group leaD.. She's on the right in the picture, with her hands crossed. She's married and has one child to support. She retails various kind of fabric : thioub, wax, and khartoum. In parallel, she also sells smoked fish.

She wishes to use her new loan to bolster her business and increase her income. Her profits enable her to renovate her house.

loans.use: to buy fabrics and smoked fish

loans.name: Sèmako Phébet

texts.fr: Née le 21 Mars 1977 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, Phébet vit depuis cinq ans à PK12, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Phébet est mariée à Pascal un revendeur, et a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Phébet  vit ensemble avec son mari et ses quatre enfants. Phébet assure ensemble avec son mari les différentes charges de la maison. Phébet n’a jamais été à l’école. Pour nourrir ses enfants et satisfaire ses besoins quotidiens, Phébet achète à Dantopka, marché international du Bénin, divers produits (conserves de tomate et de sardine, lait, mayonnaise, sucre, savons, pâtes alimentaires, insecticide, etc.), qu'elle revend à Sèmè-Podji depuis dix ans. Ce premier prêt permettra certainement à Phébet de rehausser le niveau de son activité et d’accroître sa clientèle et son revenu.
texts.en:
Born March 21, 1977 in Cotonou, Benin's economic capital, Phébet has lived in PK12, in the town of Sèmè-Podji, for five years. She is married to Pascal, a reseller, and the couple have four children who all attend school. The whole family live together, and the couple handle the various household responsibilities. 

Phébet never attended school. To support her children and look after herself, she buys various items  (canned sardines and tomatoes, milk, mayonnaise, sugar, soap, pasta, insecticide, etc.) in Dantopka, Benin’s international market, for resale in Sèmè-Podji. She has been doing this for ten years. 

This first loan will help Phébet to boost her activities and increase her customer base and her income.

loans.use: to buy various items (pasta, canned goods, milk, sugar, etc.)

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita is currently in a business of selling charcoal. She is 35 years old, married, with two children, all of them go to school. Rita will borrow a loan to stock more charcoal to sell. She hopes to expand with extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: Stock more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Purity

texts.en: Purity is 34 years old, married, and has a five-year-old child.  For three years, she has been selling clothes.  She started the business after clearing school.  With the trainings offered by Faulu Kenya, she has learned how to keep business records.  Therefore, she has been able to run her business well.  She hopes to open a boutique in the future.  She has requested 40,000 Kes to buy clothes.

loans.use: To buy clothes to resell.

loans.name: Perisila

texts.en: Perisila G. 30 is years old.  She is currently in a business of selling vegetables.  She will use this loan to stock more vegetables. She is married to a working man and they have five children in school.  Her future goal is to expand her business.

loans.use: stock more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Las Palmeras Group

texts.es:
La Sra. Olga M. es la Directora General de este comité, la misma se dedica a la venta de ropas y perfumes, ella es soltera y tiene 2 hijos pequeños, es la única que genera ingresos en su hogar y por tal motivo sería de mucha utilidad para ella y su familia el crédito que solicita a la Fundación Paraguaya y Kiva, ya que lo destinaría en su totalidad a la compra de mercaderías para la venta, como perfumes y colonias.
Este grupo del Barrio San Isidro de la ciudad de Encarnacion, surgió por contacto de las señoras  con la Fundación Paraguaya, el grupo se encuentra en el 2º ciclo, opera con la institución desde el año 2010.
Todas las mujeres son personas muy trabajadoras, luchan cada día contra todos los obstáculos que puedan tener para sobresalir, pues desean con mucha fe sacar adelante a sus familias, haceles progresar y superar la pobreza que últimamente se ha vuelto un mal generalizado en muchos sectores de nuestro país.
Las integrantes poseen muy buenas referencias crediticias, por lo que han obtenido la confianza de esta fundación en varias ocasiones, y esperan contar con la misma confianza de Kiva.
texts.en:
This group is from the San Isidro neighborhood of the city of Encarnacion. It came about thanks to the contact that its members had with Fundación Paraguaya; the group is now in its 2nd loan cycle and has been with Fundación Paraguaya since 2010.

Olga M. is the director of this group. She makes her living selling clothing and perfume; she is single and has two small children. Olga is the only breadwinner in her household so the loan she is seeking from Fundación Paraguaya and Kiva would be very useful to her and her family. She will use the loan to purchase an inventory of merchandise, such as perfume and cologne.

All the women in the group are very hardworking people; they struggle every day against all the obstacles so that they could get ahead and have an earnest desire to help their families move forward, to make progress, to overcome the poverty that has recently become a general scourge in many parts of our country.

The members have very good credit references as they have earned the trust of this foundation on several occasions; they hope to be able to have the same level of trust with Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase perfume and cologne

loans.name: Dimitri

texts.en:
Dimitri T. comes from the village of Aradeti, Kareli District. He is 57 years old, married and lives with his wife Lena and mother. Dimitri and Lena earn a living with agricultural activities. They have a milk cow and two calves. Lena makes cheese and sells it in Kareli. In addition, they have plot of land where a variety of fruits and vegetables are grown. The total average monthly income of the family is 1,100 Laris. 

Dimitri requested credit, as he needed cash for cultivating his plot. He plans to buy fuel for his tractor (for tilling) and fertilizers. He plans to sow potatoes, onions and tomatoes. He hopes that fertilizing will result in an increased volume of harvested vegetables and fruits and that the family’s income will increase. One part of the profit will be reinvested and the other part will be used for satisfying family needs.

loans.use: to pay for fuel for his tractor and to buy fertilizers

loans.name: Melanine

texts.en: Melanine is a mother of two children and she is 47 years old. Her children are between the ages of 17-26 years old, and all her children are in school. Melanine sells sodas and sorghum and she has been doing this business for 10 years. She is requesting a loan to buy more sorghum. With the profits she plans to buy cattle which will give her milk.

loans.use: To buy sorghum for sale and make more profits.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella is currently in a business of phone charging. She is 30 years old, married, with one child and goes to school. Stella borrowed a loan to stock more chargers for phone charging. She hopes to expand her business with extra profits in the future.

loans.use: Stock more chargers for phone charging.

loans.name: Raeda

texts.en:
Raeda is a 39-year-old married woman. She has four children and works in a full time job at the Ministry of Education in Jordan. She and her husband decided to start another small business to help them have more income to support the family.

Their business is selling some goods from their house including blankets, shoes, food like nuts, and other kind of goods. This business has been running for five years now. During this time, they were able to buy a bus so they can reach as many areas as they can to sell their goods.

Now Raeda is applying for a loan to add more types of goods based on their customers needs and to buy another bus in the future.

loans.use: To buy more goods based on their customers needs

loans.name: Denis

texts.en: Denis is a 30-year-old married man with two children.  He runs a retail shop to earn a living.  He also supplies milk to earn extra income.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, his business has improved hence his living standards.  He hopes to open a supermarket in the future.  He wants a loan of 30,000 Kes to buy stationery.

loans.use: To buy stationery

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.fr: Elisabeth est née en 1981 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Elisabeth a deux enfants, qui sont tous scolarisés et qui vivent avec elle. Elisabeth ne vit plus avec son mari. Il y a douze ans que Elisabeth s'est installée avec ses enfants à Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Elisabeth assure seule les charges de ses enfants. N'ayant pas été à l'école, Elisabeth  vend des gâteaux faits à base de la farine de manioc de façon ambulante. Cette activité lui procure des revenus qui lui permettent de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Elisabeth achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Elisabeth sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les deux premiers crédits ont tous été bien remboursés. Son ambition est de renforcer davantage son activité afin d'accroître son revenu.
texts.en:
Elisabeth was born in 1981 in Cotonou, Benin's economic capital. She has two children who attend school and live with her. She no longer lives with her husband. She moved to Agblangandan in the town of Sèmè-Podji 12 years ago, and she takes care of her children alone. 

Elisabeth never attended school. She sells cakes made from cassava flour door to door. The income earned from this activity allows her to support herself and her children. She buys her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. 

In order to bolster her business and better serve her customers, Elisabeth is requesting a third loan from ALIDé. The first two loans were correctly repaid. Her goal is to further strengthen her business to increase her income.

loans.use: to buy cassava flour and peanut oil to make cakes

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine S. has been running a salon in Olekuitoriori;Kitengela town for 12 years with a profit margin of KES.4,000 a month. She is married to Enock S. who is a farmer, and she is a mother of four children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by a KADET staff and she is applying for her first loan to buy seats for the salon. She will use the anticipated profit to pay school fees for her children.

In the future Josephine plans to grow her business and start a hair dressing school.

loans.use: to buy seats for her salon.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase two sacks of beans, peas, maize and rice for resale.

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en: Vicky M. is 40 years and is currently in a business of selling in a food market.  She will use her loan to stock more food for the market.  She is married to Tax Collector and they have five children all in school.  Her future goal is to pay for her children's fees.

loans.use: Stock more food for her market.

loans.name: Martina Candelaria

texts.es:
Martina, reside en Jiquilisco departamento de Usulután, vive con su esposo y sus hijos, como familia se dedican al cultivo de maíz y pipián, también a la venta de frutas, desde hace 8 años, esta venta la realiza dos semanas de cada mes, en un centro escolar, este trabajo lo realizan juntos y dependen económicamente de él.
Ella solicita un préstamo para el alquiler de terreno, son tres manzanas las que reserva para iniciar la siembra, este es todo un proceso ya que después de pagar el alquiler debe trabajar en la preparación del suelo.
Este préstamo ayudara a tener con anticipación el lugar adecuado para cultivar, el objetivo de ella es aumentar la producción de maíz y pipián, también ingresar una mayor cantidad de ganancias a su hogar.
texts.en:
Martina lives in Jiquilisco in the department of Usulután where she lives with her husband and their children. As a family they work together growing corn and pipián [squash seeds used in traditional sauces] as well as selling fruit which they have done for eight years. They sell fruit two weeks out of every month at an educational center; this work is something they perform together and they depend upon it economically. 

She is requesting a loan to pay rent on some land. Three square blocks [about 5 acres] is what she reserves in order to begin sowing their crops. It is a whole process since after paying the rent she must work to prepare the soil. 

This loan will help her to secure an appropriate place for farming ahead of time. Her objective is to increase the production of corn and pipián, and also bring in more income for her home.

loans.use: to pay rent on a plot of land.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is currently in a business of selling bread. She is 30 years old, married, with five children, all of whom go to school.  Elizabeth borrowed a loan to stock more bread to sell. She hopes to expand her business with extra profits in the future.

loans.use: Stock more bread to sell.

loans.name: Doreen

texts.en: Doreen is a hardworking married mother of three, she has no other dependents and lives in her own home in Hioma Uganda. She has a business of selling used clothes and has been doing it for the past year. She started by selling phone accessories and then saved to start this business. She faces a challenge of the business being seasonal and her desire is to own a boutique in the next two years. Doreen needs a loan to buy used clothes for resell.

loans.use: To purchase used clothes to resell.

loans.name: Peluce

texts.en: Peluce is a thirty two year old married woman with four children and she owns a house in Kasese Uganda. She has been in produce for ten years dealing in maize and beans for sell. Her hardship is limited capital and her vision is to establish outlets in different trading centers and educate her children. Peluce needs the loan facility to buy maize and beans for resell.

loans.use: To buy maize and beans for resell.

loans.name: Maria Lucelly

texts.es:
Desde hace 17 años María Lucelly ha trabajado con su mamá  en el negocio de Cafetería, es por esto que ella quiere montar su propio negocio no solo para el sustento diario de su familia sino también para que su hija tenga un lugar donde trabajar.

Su sueño es poder ofrecerles a sus clientes un excelente servicio y una gran variedad de productos, además de un espacio para compartir entre amigos, ella quiere que su negocio pase de generación en generación como su legado de vida.
texts.en:
María Lucelly has worked with her mother for 17 years in the cafeteria business.  That is why she wants to set up her own business.  She wants to do this this not only for the daily support of her family, but also so that her daughter has a place to work.

Her dream is to be able to give her customers excellent service with a great variety of products and a place to share with friends.  She hopes to pass down her business from generation to generation as her life’s legacy.

loans.use: to buy cafeteria supplies

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is a thirty eight year old married woman with six children and she owns a house in Kasese Uganda. She has been dealing in the sale of cassava flour for two years in which she started with a capital of 200,000 shillings and now has 1,000,000 shillings. Her hardship is price fluctuation and her vision is to own a food store and educate her children. Joyce needs the loan facility to buy cassava flour for sell.

loans.use: To buy cassava to sell.

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity A. is 25 years old and is currently in the business of selling vegetables.  She will use her loan to stock more vegetables. She is married to a teacher and they have three children but one child does not go to school. Her future goal is to pay for her children's fees.

loans.use: Stock more vegetables for sale.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles is 34 years and a single father of three children with no other dependents living in his own home in Hioma Uganda. For eight years he has been operating a transport business and out of it he has been able to buy a plot, however he faces a challenge of stiff competition and in the future he hopes to buy more cars to add to his business. Charles needs a loan to buy tires and overhaul his engine.

loans.use: To purchase tires and overhaul his engine.

loans.name: Mwanapili

texts.en:
Mwanapili is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are rent bills and school fees.

For the past over one year, she has operated a cassava selling business, she sells at the market to her neighbours and passersby. Mwanapili dreams of expanding and establishing a food stall in the future. With the Kshs 40,000 she is requesting she wants to purchase sacks of cassava for resale at the market. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of cassave for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase his shop’s inventory.

loans.name: Rauben

texts.en: Rauben is a thirty nine year old married man with five children and he owns a house in Kasese Uganda. He has been in the shop and bar business for ten years and this has facilitated him in paying school fees for his children and constructing a house. His hardships include limited capital and price changes of the market; however, his vision is to finish building his house and owning a big bar. Rauben needs the loan facility to buy a fridge and drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy a fridge and drinks for sale.

loans.name: Saviya

texts.en: E. is currently in a business of selling tomatoes. She is 64 years old, a widow, with four children, two of whom go to school. E. will borrow a loan to stock more tomatoes to sell. She hopes to pay her children in school with extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: Stock more tomatoes to sell.

loans.name: Santina

texts.en: Santina K. is 32 years old and is currently in a restaurant business.  She will use her loan to stock more food.  She is married to a farmer and they have two children.  Only one of the children are going to school.  Her future goal is to open a shop.

loans.use: Stock more food to sell.

loans.name: Sarepta Group

texts.fr: Kapinga N.  est entrepreneur, présidente du groupe d’affaire « Sarepta »,  âgée de 64 ans, mariée, mère de 10 enfants dont le fils ainé a 46 ans et le cadet a 26 ans. Tous ses 10 enfants ont leurs  diplômes universitaires. Son mari est un comptable dans une entreprise publique « Office national du café (ONC)». La cliente Kapinga N.  est boulangère. Elle a aussi une boutique pour  maximiser assez des revenus. Il ya 33 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité de boulangère. Elle démarra son business avec de fonds propre issu de production de récolte du champ. Cette récolte valait 6$ à l’époque. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner avec des matières premières (20 sacs de farines, sucre, levures, etc.). En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise et surtout l’espace de production et initier ses enfants dans l’auto prise en charge.  La cliente Kapinga N.  remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe d’affaire «  Sarepta » est majoritairement féminins.
texts.en: Kapinga N. is an entrepreneur and president of the "Sarepta" business group. She is 64 years old, married and mother to ten children, the eldest son being 46 years old and the youngest being 26 years old. All her ten children have got university diplomas. Her husband is an accountant in a public company, namely the National Café Office (Office national du café - ONC). The customer, Kapinga N. is a baker. She also has a shop in order to maximise her income. She has been carrying out her bakery business for the past 33 years. She started the business with a capital generated from the production of crop from the fields. This crop was worth USD 6 at the time. This new loan will allow her to get fresh supplies of basic products (20 bags of flour, sugar, yeast etc.). Her ambition for the future is to expand her business and, above all, her production space, but also to get her children started up in providing for themselves. Kapinga N. is grateful to Hekima for its actions in favour of poor people who are excluded from classic banks. It should be noted that the "Sarepta" business group is made up mainly of women.

loans.use: to buy 20 bags of flour, sugar, yeast etc..

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “MANOS JUNTAS RUMICHACA - ALTA”; Este banco está ubicado en el poblado de Rumichaca,  provincia de Urubamba y  departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Virginia; es casada, la socia tiene 8 hijos, la socia se dedica principalmente a la casa, y también a la crianza de animales menores ella compra y vende gallinas al por mayor y menor la socia desea el crédito para poder comprar 20 gallinas y de este modo incrementar sus ventas. La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de gallinas. 

La socia está muy agradecido por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de dicho préstamo de forma disciplinada.
texts.en:
The loan recipient is a member of the village bank ''Manos Juntas Rumichaca-Alta". This bank is located in the town of Rumichaca, in the province of Urubamba and the department of Cusco.

Virginia is married and has 8 children. She is primarily a housewife, and also raises small animals. She buys and sells hens in bulk and individually. She wants the loan to be able to buy 20 hens and therefore increase her sales. She asks for the loan to invest in the purchase of hens.

She is very thankful for the loan and promises to comply with the payments of the loan in a disciplined manner.

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of hens

loans.name: Mujeres En Accion Group

texts.es:
Para la formación del presente comité tuvo la iniciativa la señora Liz R.. Ella contactó con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité en su comunidad.
El comité se denomina ”Mujeres en Acción“, está en el Primer Ciclo con 18 integrantes, es un grupo que se destaca en el barrio, realizan actividades e incentivos para el grupo en caso de que alguna compañera lo necesite.
La sra. Liz se dedica a la confeccion, ella posee muchos clientes por la zona, pero los materiales para cumplir con todos los pedidos no le abastecen, pues ella no posee el dinero suficiente como para adquirirlos por cantidades que completen las necesidades de sus trabajos.
Por ello solicita el crédito, para poder comprar todos los materiales que necesita, en especial telas, pues es lo más caro que debe obtener, y lo principal.
Es su medio de ganar el ingreso necesario para poder mantener económicamente a su familia, al igual que las demás mujeres, quienes aportan a la canasta familiar con sus ganancias laborales.
texts.en:
Señora Liz R. had the initiative to set up this committee. She contacted friends and neighbors to establish the committee in her community. The committee is called "Mujeres en Acción" [Women in Action]. It is in its first loan cycle with 18 members. It is a group that stands out in the neighborhood. They plan activities and incentives for the group in case it is needed by any member. 

Señora Liz earns a living at dressmaking. She has many clients throughout the area but does not have an adequate supply of materials to complete all the orders she receives, since she does not have sufficient money to purchase in the quantities she needs to carry out her work. Thus she is requesting the loan so that she may buy all the materials she needs, especially cloth, which is the most expensive item she must get, and the most important. This is her way of earning the necessary income to be able to financially support her family, as do the other women, who also contribute to the family piggy bank with profits from their labor.

loans.use: to purchase cloth, frames, canvas, needles, button-related supplies, etc.

loans.name: Pilar

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “MANOS JUNTAS RUMICHACA - ALTA”; Este banco está ubicado en el poblado de Rumichaca,  provincia de Urubamba y  departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Pilar; es casada, la socia tiene 49 años de edad; la socia tiene 4 hijos,  de los cuales tres de ellos son independientes y uno de ellos tiene 16 años de edad; la socia tiene un pequeño abarrotes, ella vende todo tipo de productos desde los de primera necesidad, hasta las gaseosas y cervezas, la socia desea el préstamo para poder invertir en la compra de productos como arroz, azúcar, fideos, harinas y de este modo implementar su negocio. La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de productos de primera necesidad. 

La socia está muy agradecido por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de dicho préstamo de forma disciplinada.
texts.en:
This lady belongs to the community bank "Hands Together Rumichaca-Alta". This bank is located in the town of Rumichaca, in the province of Urumbamba and the department of Cusco. 
The bank member is called Pilar; she is married and 45 years old. She has 4 children, 3 of whom are grown up and one who is 16 years old. She has a small grocery store where she sells all sorts of goods from basic necessities to sodas and beers. She wants the loan to buy basic groceries such as rice, sugar, noodles, and flour, and in this way strengthen her business. She is requesting the loan to buy basic necessities. 
The bank member is very grateful for the loan and she promises to may the repayments for this loan in a disciplined way.

loans.use: to buy basic groceries to sell.

loans.name: Mwanarusi

texts.en:
Mwanarusi is a married woman with one child who is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

She has operated a tailoring business for the past three years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. In addition she also operates a cosmetic business which contributes to her other source of income. Mwanarusi faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of expanding to meet her customers needs in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she is requesting she wants to purchase cloth materials, threads and cosmetics for her cosmetic shop. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase cloth materials, threads and cosmetics for her cosmetic shop.

loans.name: Inecio

texts.es:
El señor Inecio tiene 63 años de edad, está casado con la señora Delfina Cardozo de 64 años de edad, tienen 2 hijos, viven en un barrio muy conocido de la ciudad de Itá.
El posee 2 camiones con los que realiza servicios de flete en la ciudad de Itá y alrededores, se dedica a esta actividad desde hace 21 años, gracias a su excelente trato y servicio posee una clientela muy bien formada.
Sus hijos aún viven con él, uno de ellos lo ayuda en su negocio manejando uno de sus camiones y la otra hija es estudiante, los ingresos económicos que obtiene a través de esta actividad es lo que permite que sus hijos tengan la oportunidad de salir adelante y construyan un camino de vida digna, sin andar por los vicios o delitos como otros tantos jóvenes.
El solicita el crédito a Kiva para poder comprar cubiertas nuevas para sus vehículos, ya que es muy importante para su negocio el mantenimiento correcto de ellos, pues es su medio de trabajo y lo ayudaría a continuar con su actividad.
texts.en:
Inecio is 63 years old, he is married to 64 year old Delfina and they have 2 children. They live in a very well know neighborhood of the city of Itá.
He owns 2 trucks with which her runs a freight service in the city of Itá and the surrounding area. He has been doing this since he was 21 years old. Thanks to his excellent service and treatment of his customers, he has very good client base.
His children still live with him, one of them helps him in the business driving one of the trucks and the other girl is a student. The income that he makes from this work is what enables his children to have the opportunity to be successful and create dignified lives, without walking the path of vice or crime like so many other young people. 
He is requesting a loan from Kiva to buy new tires for his vehicles as it is very important for his business that he maintains his trucks well - this is his work tool and enables him to continue his activity.

loans.use: to buy new tires.

loans.name: Margarita Del Socorro

texts.es: Margarita del Socorro se dedica a la venta de mercadería en general. Tiene 42 años, ella es una persona responsable que disfruta de tener un medio de vida. Inicio su actividad comercializando con pocos productos, tiene más de 9 años en este medio de vida. Es una persona muy trabajadora ella se levanta todos los días temprano pues sabe que tiene que alistarse con su bolso para salir a ofrecer cada uno de sus productos. El motivo del crédito es para la compra de camisas, faldas, pantalones, vestidos, trajes de baño, calzado, cosméticos y tratamientos.
texts.en: Margarita works selling general goods including clothes. She is 42 years old and she is a responsible person who enjoys earning a living. She started her business selling only a few products. She has been earning her living this way for 9 years. She is a very hardworking person and she gets up early everyday because she knows that she has to get ready with her bag to go out and sell every one of her products. The purpose of the loan is to buy shirts, skirts, pants, dresses, swim suits, shoes, cosmetics, and treatments.

loans.use: to buy shirts, skirts, pants, dresses, swim suits, shoes, cosmetics, and treatments.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a married woman with seven children, all of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past three years, she has operated a butcher shop business, selling meat as wholesale to her cafe operators and small scale operators in the area. She dreams of becoming self reliant in the business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she is requesting she wants to purchase a goat and cow for her butcher shop business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase a goat and cow for her butcher shop business.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.es:
Patricia forma parte del banco comunal “Newen” perteneciente a la ciudad de Penco. Ella se dedica a la venta de ropa y accesorios en su propia casa. Desde hace 3 años. Sin embargo, debido al terremoto del 27 de febrero del año 2010, la población quedó muy asustada y debió darle prioridad a cubrir las necesidades más básicas, por lo tanto la compra de ropa fue disminuyendo, por lo que debió añadir a su negocio la producción de pan dulce, integral y amasado, estos productos los vende a particulares en una fabrica. Por lo que sus clientes ya son frecuentes. Su mercadería de ropa y accesorios, la compra en la ciudad de Santiago, y los insumos de amasandería los compra en la ciudad de Concepción. También se dedica a la artesanía en joyas de fantasía y cristales. Éste rubro lo practica desde hace 19 años. En la actualidad también se encuentra tejiendo y vendiendo bufandas con diseños innovadores y diferentes a los del mercado. Lamentablemente el terremoto asoló su vivienda completamente, lo que le significó la perdida de todos sus materiales de trabajo y debió comenzar de cero. Tuvo que comprar de todo y además se cambió de domicilio.
Con el préstamo comprará ropa, harina de trigo y blanca, además de aceite y sal.
Sus principales sueños son pagar sus cuentas mensuales y vivir tranquila y en armonía junto a su familia. Por ende sus motivaciones de continuar con estos diversos negocios. 
Patricia vive junto a sus hijas de 28 y 27 años de edad, además su nieta de 4 años. Ella se siente muy apoyada por su entorno familiar. 
Patricia está muy contenta y agradecida del crédito obtenido por Fondo Esperanza, ya que éste le servirá para invertir en todos sus negocios y generar mejores ganancias. Además comenta que Fondo Esperanza, le brindó mucha ayuda, para el terremoto. Respecto a las reuniones, existe mucha camaradería, además le sirve para distraerse y pasar un momento agradable. Penco es una comuna cercana a la ciudad de Concepción, al sur de Chile, región del Bíobío. Su nombre  viene del mapudungun y significa "agua de peumo". Es una de las comunas con mayor cantidad de habitantes en la región. Cuenta con centros industriales y un puerto.
texts.en:
Patricia is part of the community bank "Newen" which is located in the city of Penco. She works selling clothes and accessories from her home and has been doing this for 3 years. However, owing to the earthquake of February 27th, 2010, the people here have been very scared and have had to give greater priority to more basic necessities, and therefore clothes sales have diminished. As a result she has had to expand her business by making sweet breads, wholewheat bread, and kneaded bread, and she sells these goods to the workers at a factory which means she has frequent customers. 
She buys her clothes and accessories supplies in the city of Santiago and the supplies for her baking she buys in the city of Concepción. She also makes costume jewelry. She has been doing this for 19 years. She currently also knits and sells scarves with innovative designs that are different from the ones found in the market. Lamentably, the earthquake completely devastated her home and she lost all her work materials and had to start again with nothing. She had to buy everything and also had to move home. 
She will use the loan to buy clothes, white and wholemeal flour, and oil and salt. 
Her greatest dreams are to pay her monthly expenses and live quietly and in harmony with her family. Hence her motivation to continue with these different businesses. 
Patricia lives with her daughters who are 28 and 27 years old as well as her 4 year old granddaughter. She feels very supported by her entire family.
Patricia is very happy and grateful for the loan from Fondo Esperanza, as this will be invested in all her businesses and generate greater income. She also comments that Fondo Esperanza offered her a lot of help after the earthquake. With respect to the bank meetings, there is much camaraderie, and they serve as a distraction and opportunity to pass some pleasant time together. Penco is a community close to the city of Concepción, in the south of Chile, in the Bíobío region. Its name comes from the Mapudungun and means laurel water. This is one of the most populous communities in the region and it has industrial centers and a port.

loans.use: to buy rope, wheat flour and white flour, as well as oil and salt.

loans.name: Iyali Group

texts.es: Este grupo se llama "Iyali". Está ubicado en Puebla, México. El grupo está conformado por 10 integrantes. Guadalupe S. G. es la presidente del grupo. Tiene 38 años, estudió hasta el sexto año de primaria tiene 3 hijos. Ella se dedica a la venta de zapato, inició hace 15 años. Solicita el préstamo para más pares de zapatos para su negocio. Al momento de solicitar este préstamo se siente entusiasmada con muchas ganas de sobresalir.  También espera con este préstamo obtener mejores ganancias y así obtener más clientes e invertirlo hasta que su negocio crezca y conseguir una mejor calidad de vida. La señora Reyna M. es otra integrante de este grupo, tiene 42 años, estudió hasta la secundaria. Es casada y sus hijos ya se casaron. Ella tiene una tienda, su negocio lo inicio hace 10 años ya que en ese tiempo tuvo problemas económicos ya que su esposo no tenia trabajo por lo que ella en busca de oportunidades pudo emprender su tienda que hoy en dia es muy conocida en su comunidad. Solicita el préstamo para comprar más mercancia. Al momento de solicitar este préstamo se siente entusiasmada ya que con este crédito comprará más productos y siempre tener lo que buscan sus clientes como azucar, aceites y refrescos. También espera con este préstamo tener una mejor calidad de vida para ella y su familia.
texts.en: This group is called "Iyali". It is located in Puebla, Mexico. There are 10 members of the group. Guadalupe is the president of the group. She is 38 years old and she studied until the 6th grade of primary school. She works selling shoes, and she began doing this 15 years ago. She is requesting the loan to buy more pairs of shoes. When applying for this loan, she is excited and eager to excel. She also hopes to increase her income with this loan and to get more clients so that she can grow her business and gain a better quality of life. Reyna is another member of the group. She is 42 years old and studied up to secondary school. She is married and her children are already married. She has a store and she started her business 10 years ago because, at this time, she had economic problems as her husband was out of work so she went looking for opportunities and started her store. Today the store is very well known in the community. She is requesting the loan to buy more merchandise. When applying for this loan she feels excited as she will be able to buy more goods with the loan and will always have the things her clients are looking for, like sugar, oil, and sodas. She also hopes that, with the help of this loan, she will have a better quality of life for herself and for her family.

loans.use: to buy supplies for their business.

loans.name: Keyla Naara

texts.es:
Keyla desde hace seis años, comenzó a vender cosméticos, zapato, ropa, para ayudarse económicamente, ya que su esposo labora en zona franca siendo su salario bajo.
En Afodenic encontró la oportunidad de la inversión, mediante el financiamiento, lo que 	compro mercadería variada, que ayudo a sus ventas. Captando más clientela. Hoy en día ya está viviendo en su casa propia, aun falta mucho arreglo, el cual espera mejorar a futuro.
